revision.comment: /* History */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} The '''12th man''' or 12th player is a term for [[Fan (person)|fans]] of teams in eleven-a-side sports games, particularly [[association football]] (soccer) or [[American football]]. As most football leagues allow a maximum of eleven players per team on the playing field at a time, referring to a team's fans as the 12th man implies that they have a potentially helpful role in the game. Infrequently, the term has referred to individuals having a notable connection to their football team. In [[Canadian football]], 12 players are usually on the field at one time and the term '''13th man''' is often used to refer to fans. Similarly, in [[Australian rules football]], 18 players are on the field and the fans are often referred to as the '''19th man'''. The term has a different meaning in [[cricket]], referring instead to the [[Glossary of cricket terms#T|first substitute player]] who fields when a member of the fielding side is injured (the term '''6th man''' has a similar connotation in [[basketball]]).
The presence of fans can have a profound impact on how the teams perform, an element in the [[home advantage]]. Namely, the home team fans would like to see their team win the game. Thus these fans will often create loud sounds or [[football chant|chant]] in hopes of distracting, demoralizing and confusing the opposing team while they have possession of the ball; or to persuade a referee to make a favorable decision. Noises are made by shouting, whistling, stomping and various other techniques.
==History== [[File:E king hill 12thman.jpg|thumb|right|120px|Texas A&M's E. King Gill during the 1921–1922 season]]
The first recorded use of the term "twelfth man" was a magazine published by the [[University of Minnesota]] in September, 1900, that referred to "the mysterious influence of the twelfth man on the team, the rooter."<ref>{{cite journal |title=Editorial |journal=Minnesota Magazine |volume=7 |issue=September 1900 |page=32 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5b4NAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA32 |publisher= University of Minnesota |author=Unknown}}</ref> Later, in the November 1912 edition of The Iowa Alumnus, an alumni publication of the [[University of Iowa]] (then known as State University of Iowa), E.A. McGowan described the 1903 game between [[1903 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Iowa]] and the [[1903 Illinois Fighting Illini football team|University of Illinois]]. In his article, titled "The Twelfth Player" McGowan wrote: "The eleven men had done their best; but the twelfth man on the team (the loyal spirited Iowa rooter) had won the game for old S.U.I."<ref>{{cite journal |title=The Twelfth Player |journal=The Iowa Alumnus |volume=10 |issue=November 1912 |page=30 |url=http://digital.lib.uiowa.edu/cdm/compoundobject/collection/uap/id/5706/rec/10 |publisher= University of Iowa. Alumni Association |author=E. A. McGowan}}</ref>
The [[1922 Dixie Classic]] served as the setting for an event later referred to as "The story of the 12th Man."<ref>{{cite book|title=Sports and Understanding Organizations|editor=Daniel J. Svyantek|publisher=Information Age Publishing|location=Charlotte, North Carolina|year=2017|page=44|isbn=978-1681237923}}</ref> This football game featured the top-ranked [[1921 Centre Praying Colonels football team|Centre College]] and [[1921 Texas A&M Aggies football team|The Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas]] (later known as Texas A&M). During the game, A&M coach [[Dana X. Bible]] realized that one more injury would leave him without another backfield player to send into the game. <ref>{{cite book|title=ESPN College Football Encyclopedia: The Complete History of the Game|editor=Michael MacCambridge|publisher=ESPN Books|location=New York, NY|year=2005|page=44|isbn=978-1401337032}}</ref>. Bible called E. King Gill, a sophomore basketball player, down from the stands to stand ready as a substitute. Gill was ready in uniform on the sidelines if his team ever needed him. Gill never went in the game, but his spirit that lives on in the "12th Man."
Individuals have occasionally been labeled by local media as the "Twelfth Man" of their team. In 1930, W. H. Adamson, Principal of Oak Cliff (Dallas) High School was called the "Twelfth Man" of the school's American football team by a local reporter due to the rousing pre-game speeches he would give to the players.
In the 1935 [[1935 Princeton Tigers football team|Princeton]]-{{cfb link|year=1935|team=Dartmouth Big Green|school=Dartmouth College|title=Dartmouth}} game before 56,000 fans who braved the snow and cold,<ref>{{cite web|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=December 23, 1935|title=Oddities in 1935 Sports|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19351223&id=rbIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dZsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3344,5154533}}</ref> spectator Mike Mesco was initially reported to have left his seat from the stands to join the Dartmouth defensive line and was referred to in a local newspaper as the "Twelfth Dartmouth Man."<ref>{{cite news|title=none|newspaper=World Telegram|date=November 30, 1935}}</ref> As it turned out it was not Mesko but George Larsen of Cranford, N.J., who dashed from the stands to aid Dartmouth in her game with Princeton.<ref>{{cite news|title=Yale's Error! Fetes Wrong Butt-In Hero|last=Alexander|first=Jack|newspaper=Sunday News|date=December 1, 1935}}</ref> Asa Bushnell III, Princeton class of 1947, wrote of the incident in 1960 for the Princeton Athletic News: "Strange as it may seem, it was a young architect from Cranford, N.J., a refugee{{clarify|date=January 2017}} from the University of Cincinnati, no less - who immortalized the activities in Palmer Stadium on November 23, 1935. It was he who, midway through the fourth period that tingling afternoon, left the other 55,999 spectators in their seats to assist the Dartmouth Indians in a determined goal-line stand. It was he who lined up with the Hanoverians on the two yard stripe and prevented Jack White from scoring - and White boasted interference from the awesome likes of Johnny Weller and Homer Spofford. It was the daring "twelfth man" who, though escorted unceremoniously off the field and out of the stadium without further ado, gained a nationwide American football reputation in a single play."<ref>{{cite book|year=2001|title=Rites of Autumn, The Story of College Football|last=Whittingham|first=Richard}}</ref>
The December 18, 1938, ''Dallas Morning News'' said "Whether they play now on a team, used to play back in the day, follow the game closely or just quarterback from the grandstand occasionally, every American football enthusiast well knows how much that twelfth man in the stands means to any American football team. But that backing means unusually much in the traditional Thanksgiving game between the University of Texas and Texas A&M. With an uncertain monotony that has long since made game forecasters exceedingly skittish, these two win where their twelfth men help most." Thus, in this single instance, the term "Twelfth Man" was used to refer to the fans of both schools playing.<ref>{{cite news |title=Twelfth Men |newspaper=Dallas Morning News |date=December 18, 1938 |issue=195 |url=http://www.hornsports.com/docs/aggy/DMN_Dec_18_1938.pdf |publisher= Dallas Morning News}}</ref>
==Use in association football== [[File:DC12thmanontour.JPG|thumb|[[Derry City FC|Derry City's]] twelfth man in [[Paris]], France.]]
The term "12th man" is commonly used in football to refer to [[Association football culture#Fans|the fans]] and occasionally the manager. A notable club famous for the twelfth man reference comes from [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], referring to the Holte End stand at Villa Park. Large European and Asian teams such as [[Bayern Munich]], [[Foolad F.C.|Foolad]], [[Malmö FF]], [[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]], [[Werder Bremen]], [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]], [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]], [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]], [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]], [[Feyenoord]], [[Ferencvárosi TC]], [[Red Star Belgrade|FC Red Star]], [[Fenerbahçe S.K.]], and [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting CP]] have officially retired the number 12 to the fans. [[Stockport County fans]] are registered as official members of their squad with the number 12.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} [[Portsmouth F.C.]] has also retired its number 12 shirt, and lists the club's supporters, "Pompey Fans", as player number 12 on the squad list printed in home match programmes,{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} while [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] have theirs registered to the ''Green Army'' (the nickname for their fans).{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Number 12 is also reserved for the fans at many other clubs, including [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]] and [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] in Russia, [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] and [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] in England, as well as [[Aarhus Gymnastikforening]] (AGF), [[Odense Boldklub]], also known as [[Odense Boldklub|OB]], in Denmark, [[Malmö FF]] and [[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF]] in Sweden and [[Perth Glory FC|Perth Glory]] in Australia. On [[Hammarby Fotboll|Hammarby IF's]], [[Feyenoord]] and [[Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen's]] home games, the stadium speaker announces number 12 as "the fans" during team lineup announcements.
[[Dynamo Dresden]] in Germany also keeps number 12 for their fans, as well as the official team anthem being "We are the 12th man". [[Aberdeen F.C.]] supporters commonly display a large banner in the shape of a football shirt with the text "Red Army 12" in place of a player's name and number.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} The fans of the [[Northern Ireland national football team]] and [[Derry City F.C.|Derry City]] are referred to as the 12th man as well. In the [[League of Ireland]] [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.]] retired the number 12 jersey in recognition of the fans who took over the club in 2005. [[Cork City Football Club|Cork City F.C.]], [[Clube Atlético Mineiro]] and [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]] also retired the number 12 for the fans.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} The most vociferous fans of [[Boca Juniors]] in Argentina are known as the "Jugador Numero 12" (Spanish for "Player Number 12") or simply "La Doce" ("The 12"). On September 18, 2004, [[U.S. Lecce]], an Italian team currently playing in [[Serie A]], retired the number 12 to the fans, which was handed to them by the former captain [[Cristian Daniel Ledesma|Cristian Ledesma]]. They symbolically represent a 12th Man in the field.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} In the beginning of 2009/2010 season, [[Happy Valley AA]] introduced the club's mascot, a panda, on squad list as the fan club captain wearing the number 12 jersey.<ref>{{cite web | title = HVAA Player Profile | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/norfolk/content/articles/2005/03/02/sport_delia_smith_interview_20050302_feature.shtml | accessdate =October 10, 2009 }}</ref> As of the end of the 2011/2012 season [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers F.C]] announced that the number 12 jersey would be retired in honour of the fans support throughout a period of financial difficulty.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rangers.co.uk/news/football-news/article/2757323 |publisher=rangers.co.uk |title=Rangers Dedicate No 12 Jersey to Fans |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607133516/http://www.rangers.co.uk/news/football-news/article/2757323 |archivedate=June 7, 2012}}</ref>
==Use in American football== [[File:12th Man Flag.jpg|thumb|right|The 12th Man flag of the Seattle Seahawks]] The term has been used by various American football teams including the University of Minnesota, the University of Iowa, Baylor University, Dartmouth College, Simmons College, Texas A&M and the [[NFL]]'s [[Seattle Seahawks]], [[Green Bay Packers]], [[Buffalo Bills]], [[Denver Broncos]], [[Washington Redskins]], [[Indianapolis Colts]], [[Miami Dolphins]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Major|first=Andy|title=Dolphins' owner: Parcells OK with glitz and celebrities |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d812d651e/article/dolphins-owner-parcells-ok-with-glitz-and-celebrities/|publisher=Associate Press|date=September 22, 2009|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref> and [[Chicago Bears]] in marketing practices in reference to their supporters. The Bears currently use the phrase "4th Phase" (with the first three phases being offense, defense, and special teams),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fanclub.chicagobears.com/|title=Fan Club|work=[[Chicago Bears]]|accessdate=January 4, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529185222/http://fanclub.chicagobears.com/ |archivedate=May 29, 2012}}</ref> and the Seahawks currently use the phrase "The 12s." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seahawks.com/spirit-of-12/history-of-the-12s|title=The 12s|work=Seattle Seahawks|access-date=October 12, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203012510/http://www.seahawks.com/spirit-of-12/history-of-the-12s|archive-date=December 3, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== 12th Man clubs === Many high schools in the United States incorporate 12th Man language into their booster, supporter, or rooter clubs. Examples of such "12th Man Clubs" include the [[Alta Loma High School|Alta Loma Braves]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hometeamsonline.com/teams/default.asp?u=12THMANCLUB|title=Braves Football Home Page|publisher=}}</ref> [[Dana Hills High School|Dana Hills Dolphins]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danahillsfootball.com/12thmanclub.html|title=Page not found|publisher=}}</ref> [[Washington Community High School|Washington Panthers]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peorian.com/sports/1310-high-school-sports-rule|title=High School Sports Rule|author=Mark Kiel|work=The Peorian}}</ref> [[Richwoods High School|Richwood Knights]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pjstar.com/x1101047136/Time-to-open-the-gates-for-high-school-football|title=Time to open the gates for high school football|author=Lonnie Schwindenhammer AND Stan Morris|work=Journal Star}}</ref> [[Diamond Bar High School|Diamond Bar Brahmas]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brahmafootball.com/12th-man-club.html |title=12th MAN CLUB |work=DIAMOND BAR HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223040547/http://www.brahmafootball.com/12th-man-club.html |archivedate=February 23, 2014 |df= }}</ref> [[Fairfield, California#Schools|Fairfield Falcons]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.12thmanclub.org/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202174322/http://www.12thmanclub.org/|title=12th Man Club|archivedate=February 2, 2015|publisher=}}</ref> and [[Brentwood High School (Brentwood, Tennessee)|Brentwood Bruins]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentwoodfootball.com/|title=Brentwood Bruin Football|publisher=}}</ref>
The [[Campbellsville University|Campbellsville University Tigers]] of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] also have a 12th Man Club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.campbellsvilletigers.com/article/1815.php |title=Campbellsville University Athletics News |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221180323/http://www.campbellsvilletigers.com/article/1815.php |archivedate=February 21, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
=== Buffalo Bills === [[File:1992 Buffalo Bills 12th Man Coin.png|thumb|Buffalo Bills 12th Man coin, from the December 12, 1992, [[Buffalo Bills Wall of Fame|Wall of Fame]] induction.]]
On December 12, 1992, (12/12/1992) the [[Buffalo Bills]] of the [[National Football League]] honored their 12th Man as the seventh inductee into the [[Buffalo Bills Wall of Fame]], located inside of [[New Era Field]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.buffalobills.com/2012/12/12/bdc-1212-dt-ross-added-to-53-man-roster/ |title=Bills Daily Charge |publisher=Buffalo Bills |date=December 12, 2012 | accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> Their fans were inducted because of their loyal support during the team's [[List of Buffalo Bills seasons|early '90s]] [[Super Bowl]] runs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.buffalobills.com/Wall+of+Fame |title=Buffalo Bills History - Wall of Fame |publisher=[[Buffalo Bills]] |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130322051055/http://www.history.buffalobills.com/Wall+of+Fame |archivedate=March 22, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2008, the Bills renamed their "12th Man Walk of Fame" as "[[Tim Russert]] Plaza," in honor of the Buffalo native and lifelong fan.<ref>{{cite web|last=Major|first=Andy|title=Russert forever remembered by Bills |url=http://www.buffalobills.com/news/article-1/Russert-forever-remembered-by-Bills/b91310aa-6741-40c1-be12-d24d263e6e14/|publisher=Buffalo Bills|date=November 6, 2013|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref> The team continues to refer to their fans as the "12th Man,"<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.buffalobills.com/2010/11/28/bills-calling-on-12th-man/ | work=Buffalo Bills | first=Chris | last=Brown | title=Bills calling on 12th man | date=November 28, 2010 | accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.buffalobills.com/2011/09/14/fitz-on-home-field-edge/ | work=Buffalo Bills | first=Chris | last=Brown | title=Fitz on home field edge | date=September 14, 2011 | accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.buffalobills.com/2009/12/11/fan-friday-12-11/ | work=Buffalo Bills | first=Chris | last=Brown | title=Fan Friday 12-11 | date=December 11, 2009 | accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> with their independent, international fan clubs known as "Bills Backers Chapters."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalobills.com/fans/billsbackers/|title=Bills Backers - Buffalo Bills|publisher=}}</ref> The Bills have a licensing agreement with Texas A&M over the use of the "12th Man" term.<ref>Taylor, John (July 2, 2014). [http://collegefootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2014/07/02/am-up-in-arms-over-buffalo-bills-fans-12th-man-petition/ A&M up in arms over Buffalo Bills fans’ ’12th Man’ petition]. ''CollegeFootballTalk.com''. Retrieved July 2, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lester |first1=Sean |title=To protect trademark, Texas A&M sends 12th Man usage complaint to double amputee, cancer survivor |url=http://collegesportsblog.dallasnews.com/2014/07/texas-ams-latest-12th-man-lawsuit-target-buffalo-bills-fans.html |publisher=Dallas News |accessdate=July 7, 2014 |date=July 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714233836/http://collegesportsblog.dallasnews.com/2014/07/texas-ams-latest-12th-man-lawsuit-target-buffalo-bills-fans.html/ |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
=== Indianapolis Colts === Fans of the [[Indianapolis Colts]] of the [[National Football League|NFL]] are known as the 12th Man.<ref name="ESPNColts">{{cite web|last=Wells|first=Mike|title=The Colts have their own 12th Man|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/indianapolis-colts/post/_/id/1149/the-colts-have-their-own-12th-man|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=February 21, 2014|date=October 7, 2013}}</ref> The Colts created a [[Indianapolis Colts Ring of Honor|Ring of Honor]] on September 23, 1996, after [[List of Indianapolis Colts seasons|playing 13 seasons]] in [[Indianapolis, Indiana|Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]]. In 2007, the Colts inducted their 12th Man as the sixth entrant into the team's Ring of Honor, then located on the interior facade of the [[RCA Dome]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.indystar.com/article/20071231/SPORTS03/712310383/Sanders-already-repaying-Colts | work=Indianapolis Star | first=Mike | last=Chappell | title=Sanders already repaying Colts | date=December 31, 2007 | accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref> The Ring of Honor currently encircles [[Lucas Oil Stadium]], the team's home venue. The organization also designates a "12th Man Fan of the Game".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fredericknewspost.com/archive/damascus-woman-becomes-th-man-for-pro-team/article_3fefd672-012b-5b7a-bc14-ad8fbb7b6084.html |title=Damascus woman becomes 12th man for pro team|date=September 5, 2009|work=Frederick News-Post|author=Gina Gallucci-White| accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kcautv.com/story/23127347/sioux-city-hospice-patient-lifelong-colts-fan-attends-first-ever-game |title=Sioux City Hospice Patient & Lifelong Colts Fan Attends First Ever Game|date=August 13, 2013|work=KCAU-TV|author=Staci DaSilva| accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkw.com/dr-james-malec-honored-as-colts-12th-man-fan-of-the-game/|title=Dr. James Malec Honored as Colts 12th Man Fan of the Game|work=Wilson Kehoe Winingham}}</ref> On November 12, 2015, Texas A&M announced the filing of a lawsuit against the Colts based on the team's usage of the term.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/14113722/texas-aggies-sue-indianapolis-colts-use-12th-man-trademark|title=Texas A&M Aggies sue Indianapolis Colts over use of '12th Man' trademark|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> On February 17, 2016, the lawsuit was settled with the Colts agreeing to remove the phrase from their Ring of Honor and to immediately cease all other uses of the trademarked phrase.<ref name="indystar.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.indystar.com/story/sports/2016/02/18/indianapolis-colts-jim-irsay-12th-man-texas-am/80564736/|title=Indianapolis Colts agree to stop using '12th Man' in settlement with Texas A&M|date=February 18, 2016|work=Indianapolis Star}}</ref>
=== Seattle Seahawks === The [[Seattle Seahawks]] retired the number 12 jersey on December 15, 1984, in honor of their fans. In 2003, the Seahawks installed a giant flagpole in the south end zone of what is now [[CenturyLink Field]], and began a tradition of raising a giant flag with the number 12 on it in honor of the fans, but one of whom is [[Sam Adkins (American football)|Sam Adkins]], the former Seahawks quarterback who did wear the number 12<ref>{{Citation|last=NFL Films|title=The Only Man to Wear 12 For the Seattle Seahawks {{!}} NFL Films Presents|date=2017-10-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jNwF5B0t1TM|accessdate=2017-10-16}}</ref>. Usually, a local celebrity or a season ticket holder raises the flag during pregame ceremonies.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.seahawks.com/gameday/12th-man/history.html|title=HISTORY OF THE 12TH MAN|date=|work=Seahawks.com|author=Staff|accessdate=December 20, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528225148/http://www.seahawks.com/gameday/12th-man/history.html|archive-date=May 28, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In recent years, 12th Man flags<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seahawks.com/12th-Man/|title=The 12s|work=Seattle Seahawks}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ballard|first=Chris|title=Into the belly of beast mode with Seattle's 12th Man|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/nfl/news/20131106/russell-wilson-seattle-seahawks/|publisher=Sports Illustrated|date=November 6, 2013|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Roberts|first=Chris|title=Seattle Seahawks 12th Man Flag to Torment 49ers Fans|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Seattle-Seahawks12th-Man-Flag-To-Torment-49er-Fans--243428911.html|publisher=NBC Bay Area|date=February 4, 2014|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=World's largest 12th Man flag unfurled|url=http://www.kirotv.com/news/news/worlds-largest-12th-man-flag/nc7wz/ |publisher=KIRO TV|date=January 30, 2014|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jordan Stead & Joshua Trujillo|title=12th Man flag unfolds under Lady Liberty|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/sports/football/slideshow/12th-Man-flag-unfolds-under-Lady-Liberty-78887.php |publisher=Seattle PI|date=January 31, 2014|accessdate=February 16, 2014}}</ref> have been seen all over Seattle whenever the Seahawks make the playoffs, including atop the [[Space Needle]]. In 2014, [[Boeing]] painted a [[Boeing 747-8]] freighter with a special Seahawks livery, with the number 12 on the tail, and they later flew it over eastern Washington in a flight path spelling the number 12.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mutzabaugh|first1=Ben|title=Boeing rolls out a mean-looking Seahawks 747 jumbo jet|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/todayinthesky/2014/01/30/boeing-rolls-out-a-747-jumbo-jet-painted-for-the-seahawks/5052387/|accessdate=2 June 2014|work=[[USA TODAY]]|date=30 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/travel/2014/01/31/boeing-747-flies-seahawks-12-pattern-over-washington/ | work=Fox News | title=Boeing unveils Seattle Seahawks 747 plane | date=January 31, 2014}}</ref> When the Seahawks took the field for [[Super Bowl XLVIII]], they were led by LB [[Heath Farwell]] carrying the team's 12th Man flag<ref>{{cite web|last=COHEN|first=RACHEL|title=SUPER BOWL WATCH: SEATTLE SOARING IN SUPER BOWL|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/super-bowl-watch-welcome-new-jersey|publisher=AP|accessdate=April 1, 2014|date=February 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-game-highlights/0ap2000000323054/Super-Bowl-XLVIII-Seahawks-vs-Broncos-highlights|title=Super Bowl XLVIII: Seahawks vs. Broncos highlights|work=NFL.com}}</ref> per team tradition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&file_id=10730|title=Seattle Seahawks win Super Bowl in a rout on February 2, 2014.|publisher=}}</ref>
The Seahawks' 12th Man has twice set the [[Guinness World Record]] loudest crowd noise at a sporting event, first on September 15, 2013, registering 136.6 [[Decibel|dB]] during a game against the [[San Francisco 49ers]]<ref name="noise1.1">{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Ryan|title=Seahawks fans set Guinness World Record for loudest stadium|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/23678037/seahawks-fans-sets-guinness-world-record-for-loudest-stadium|publisher=CBS Sports|accessdate=October 13, 2014|date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> <ref name="noise1.2">{{cite web|title=12th Man lifts CenturyLink Field into Guinness World Record book for loudest stadium|url=http://www.seahawks.com/news/2013/09/15/12th-man-lifts-centurylink-field-guinness-world-record-book-loudest-stadium|publisher=Seahawks.com|accessdate=February 23, 2016|date=September 15, 2013}}</ref> and again on December 2, 2013, during a [[Monday Night Football]] game against the [[New Orleans Saints]], with a roar of 137.6 dB.<ref name="noise2.1">{{cite web|last=Florio|first=Mike |title=12th Man sets new noise record|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2013/12/02/12th-man-sets-new-noise-record/|publisher=Pro Football Talk|accessdate=February 23, 2016|date=December 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name="noise2.2">{{cite web|last=Quinton|first=Sean |title=Seattle’s 12th Man reclaims Guinness crowd noise record|url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/football/2013/12/02/seattles-12th-man-reclaims-guinness-crowd-noise-record/|publisher=Seattle PI|accessdate=February 23, 2016|date=December 2, 2013}}</ref> As per an agreement struck between the Seahawks and Texas A&M in 2016, the Seahawks have virtually ceased from referring to their fans as the "12th Man",<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rovell|first1=Darren|title=Seahawks reach 5-years licensing deal with Texas A&M|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/17274864/texas-affies-lends-12th-man-trademark-seattle-seahawks-5-year-deal.html|website=ESPN|accessdate=August 11, 2016}}</ref> and instead are using the term "12s".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.seahawks.com/spirit-of-12/history-of-the-12s |title=The 12s |publisher=[[Seattle Seahawks]] |access-date=October 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203012510/http://www.seahawks.com/spirit-of-12/history-of-the-12s |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="espn.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/17274864/texas-aggies-lends-12th-man-trademark-seattle-seahawks-5-year-deal|title=Seahawks ink $140K deal with A&M for 12th Man|publisher=}}</ref>
===Texas A&M=== {{See also|Traditions of Texas A&M University}} [[File:12th Man trademark slogan at Kyle Field, Texas A&M.jpg|thumb|left|The Texas A&M [[student section]] of [[Kyle Field]] stands the entire game to show support for the [[college football|football]] team]] The first known instance of Texas A&M referring to its fanbase as the "12th Man" is contained on page 17 of 25 November 1921 edition of ''The Battalion'', the Texas A&M campus newspaper.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Twelfth Man |newspaper=The Battalion |volume=10|issue=November 25, 1921 |page=17 |url=http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r248/ianaggie/12man.jpg |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131124321/http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r248/ianaggie/12man.jpg |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-31 |publisher= Students Association of the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas |author=Unknown}} </ref> Ever since the day E. King Gill left the stands in 1922, the entire student body has stood throughout the game to symbolize their "readiness, desire, and enthusiasm" to take the field if needed.<ref name="Uncle Sam">{{cite news |title=Texas Ag of Twelfth Man Fame Serving Uncle Sam |newspaper=Dallas Morning News |issue=16 July 1942 |url=http://www.hornsports.com/docs/aggy/DMN_Jul_16_1942.pdf |publisher= Dallas Morning News |author=AP Newswire}}</ref>{{better citation|date=March 2018}}<!--picture of an apparent, undated AP newspaper article--> A statue of E. King Gill stands on the campus.<ref name="beano">{{cite web|last=Cook|first=Beano|title=Ten Days That Shook the Sport|publisher=ESPN|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2615391|date=October 8, 2006|accessdate=July 26, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=ESPN College Football Encyclopedia: The Complete History of the Game|editor=Michael MacCambridge|publisher=ESPN Books|location=New York, NY|year=2005|page=25|isbn=978-1401337032}}</ref>
Football coach [[Jackie Sherrill]] created the "12th Man Kick-Off Team" in the 1980s, composed of non-athletic scholarship students who tried out for the team. Coach Sherrill has written a book entitled "No Experience Required" which details this team and the tradition. These students were placed on the roster for the sole purpose of kickoffs. The squad was nicknamed "the suicide squad". These students often had little regard for their safety and were determined to make a tackle at any cost. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Durham|first1=Timothy|title=12th Man honors Sherrill|url=http://www.thebatt.com/2.8484/12th-man-honors-sherrill-1.1185209|website=The Battalion|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111230623/http://www.thebatt.com/2.8484/12th-man-honors-sherrill-1.1185209#.Ug3hNX3LfK4|archivedate=January 11, 2012|date=September 29, 2008}}</ref><ref name=NBCref>{{cite news|title=NBC Evening News |publisher=Vanderbilt Television News Archive |url=http://tvnews.vanderbilt.edu/program.pl?ID=532988 |date=September 2, 1983 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5h5lmsYJM?url=http://tvnews.vanderbilt.edu/program.pl?ID=532988 |archivedate=May 27, 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=May 22, 2009 |df=mdy }}</ref> The 12th Man Kick-Off Team was extremely successful and eventually held opponents to one of the lowest yards-per-return average in the league during kickoffs.{{when|date=October 2014}}<ref name="12thMan">{{cite web|url=http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/12thman.shtml |title=Twelfth Man |accessdate=December 31, 2006 |publisher=Aggie Traditions |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061229030439/http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/12thman.shtml |archivedate=December 29, 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Later, head coach [[R. C. Slocum]] changed the team to allow only one representative of the 12th Man on the kick off team who wears uniform number 12.<ref name="beano"/> The player is chosen based on the level of determination and hard work shown in practices. Under [[Dennis Franchione]], the 12th Man Kick-Off Team composed of walk-ons was brought back, though used only rarely when the team was up by quite a few points.<ref name="Kickoff">{{cite news |url = http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=sports&id=3452486 |title = McNeil sets Aggie offense record in win over SMU |date = September 17, 2005 |agency=Associated Press |publisher = [[KTRK-TV]] |deadurl=yes |archivedate=November 11, 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051111004328/http://abclocal.go.com/ktrk/story?section=sports&id=3452486 }}</ref><ref name="heater">{{Cite news |last=Heater |first=Jay |title=LaMantia A&M's main 12th Man |newspaper=[[Oakl. Trib.]] {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} |date=December 27, 2006 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-5761605.html }}</ref>
On June 30, 2014, Texas A&M bought the domain name 12thman.com, which then became its official athletics website.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.chron.com/sportsupdate/2014/07/texas-am-purchases-12thman-com-domain-for-athletics/#20782101=0 |title=Texas A&M purchases 12thMan.com domain for athletics |first=David |last=Barron |work=Sports Update |publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.12thman.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=27300&ATCLID=209536776 |title=Texas A&M Secures Ownership of 12thman.com |publisher=Texas A&M Athletics |date=July 7, 2014 |accessdate=August 2, 2014}}</ref>
===Washington Redskins=== In 1986, the [[Washington Redskins]] released a [[music video|video]] entitled "Thanks to the 12th Man".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/video/video.php?v=10151341262304574|title=Washington Redskins|website=www.facebook.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Tinsman|first1=Brian|title=NFL.com ‘Grammy’ For Redskins Fan Video|url=http://blog.redskins.com/tag/thanks-to-the-12th-man/|website=Redskins.com|publisher=Washington Redskins|accessdate=October 14, 2014|date=February 15, 2012}}</ref> A blogger on NFL.com considered it to be among the worst sports videos of all time.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rank|first1=Adam|title=And the Grammy for worst sports video ever by a team:|url=http://blogs.nfl.com/2012/02/12/and-the-grammy-for-worst-sports-video-ever-by-a-team/|website=NFL.com|publisher=National Football League|accessdate=October 14, 2014|date=February 12, 2012}}</ref>
==Other usage== In American football, the sideline is sometimes also referred to as the "12th man" or "12th defender": since a player is considered down when he steps out of bounds, the sideline effectively acts as an extra defender. This usage is less common than the one referring to the fans. The term can also be construed to mean the [[referee (association football)|referee]], implying that the match official favours one team and is not impartial.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38576689 |title=Bacary Sagna: Man City defender charged by FA for Instagram post |date=2017-01-10 |website=[[BBC Sport]]|quote=The Football Association allege that the defender's post, which was later deleted, "questioned the integrity of the match official".|access-date=2017-01-12}}</ref>
==Effects== The effects of the "12th man" vary widely, but can be put in two categories. The first is simply psychological, the effect of showing the home team that they are appreciated, and showing the away team that they are somewhat unwelcome. The second directly relates to the deafening effects of a loud crowd.
In association football, the crowd is very passionate and often sing throughout the whole match. Some occasions where the crowd noise is extra loud can be before kickoff; during the buildup to and scoring of a [[Goal (sport)|goal]]; when encouraging the team to come back from defeat; to discourage an opposition penalty taker; or to harass a [[Referee (association football)|referee]] giving a free kick to the opposition team.
In American football, fans are most incited by physical play, especially good plays made by the defense.<ref name="boling">{{Cite news|last=Boling |first=Dave |title=Artificial noise? Much ado about Hawks' 12th Man |url=http://dwb.thenewstribune.com/sports/seahawks/story/6109599p-5353332c.html |newspaper=The News Tribune |location=Tacoma, Washington |date=September 21, 2006 |accessdate=September 11, 2007 |postscript= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117052537/http://dwb.thenewstribune.com/sports/seahawks/story/6109599p-5353332c.html |archivedate=November 17, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Additionally, the home team can derive energy from the loud noise of their fans; former American football players have described the feeling of their adrenaline pumping after hearing the fans yell, which is "like you have a reserve energy tank."<ref name=baldinger/>
The noise of the crowd can have a significant impact on the players on the field. In American football, an extremely loud crowd can prevent the [[offensive linemen]] from hearing the [[snap count]]. This can have the effect of making the player slower to react when the ball is snapped, and his eventual response may be weaker than normal because each play is begun "with some indecision and doubt".<ref name=baldinger>{{Cite news |last=Baldinger |first=Brian |title=Gaps in action can kill home-field edge |newspaper=The Sporting News |date=January 12, 2004 |accessdate=September 11, 2007 |url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/11863789/gaps-action-can-kill-home-field-edge }}</ref> The noise can also prevent players from hearing [[American football|audibles]] and can make it difficult for the team's offense to coordinate plays in the huddle. The effect of the noise can often be measured in mistakes, such as [[false start]] penalties.<ref name=acee>{{Cite news|last=Acee |first=Kevin |title=They're right on Q |newspaper=[[The San Diego Tribune]] |date=December 26, 2006 |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061226/news_1s26chargers.html |accessdate=September 11, 2007 |postscript= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061227164227/http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061226/news_1s26chargers.html |archivedate=December 27, 2006 |df= }}</ref>
Coaches can take steps to minimize the effect of the crowd noise on their teams. Some American football teams bring large speakers to their practice fields and broadcast loud noises such as jet engines to prepare their teams for the anticipated noise level.<ref>{{cite news|title=Panthers thrive in hostile environments|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/2006/01/21/pro_47980.shtml|accessdate=2 June 2014|work=[[The Augusta Chronicle]]|date=21 January 2006}}</ref> Crowd noise tends to diminish after a long lull in play, such as a pause for [[instant replay]]. Former [[National Football League|NFL]] player [[Brian Baldinger]] speculates that some coaches draw out reviews as part of a coaching strategy to quiet the crowd for their next play.<ref name=baldinger/>
A researcher from [[Harvard University]] discovered in a study that some football referees appeared to be impacted by crowd noise. His studies revealed that a home team acquired an additional 0.1 goal advantage for every 10,000 fans in the stadium.<ref name=bbc>{{Cite journal|title=Study reveals referees' home bias|publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/6629397.stm|date=May 6, 2007|accessdate=September 11, 2007|postscript=}}</ref>
[[Delia Smith]], [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]'s joint major shareholder, received some attention when she took to the pitch during a half time interval, with a microphone in hand and [[British Sky Broadcasting|Sky TV]] cameras in tow, to tell fans the side "need their twelfth man". "Where are you?" she cried. [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] lost the game in the final seconds, but Smith's passion worked to increase the affection the fans held for her.<ref>{{cite web | title = Delia Smith BBC interview | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/norfolk/content/articles/2005/03/02/sport_delia_smith_interview_20050302_feature.shtml | accessdate=May 11, 2006 }}</ref>
The current naturally loudest football stadium is the Turk Telecom Arena, in Turkey, host of the Galatasaray team<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1821923-loudest-stadiums-in-world-football|title=Loudest Stadiums in World Football|first=Karla Villegas|last=Gama|publisher=}}</ref>. As a prepared attempt, the current world record for crowd noise at an athletic event was set on September 29, 2014, when the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] hosted the [[New England Patriots]]. Noise during that event reached a high of 142.2 decibels during a [[Time-out (sport)|timeout]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=FUSSELL|first1=JAMES A.|title=KC Chiefs pay thousands to proclaim ‘loudest stadium’ record|url=http://www.kansascity.com/living/article2496723.html|website=kansascity.com|publisher=THE KANSAS CITY STAR|accessdate=October 14, 2014|date=October 3, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/1/loudest-crowd-roar-at-a-sports-stadium|title=Loudest crowd roar at a sports stadium|publisher=}}</ref>
==Texas A&M trademark== Texas A&M University applied on December 26, 1989, for trademark U.S. Ser. No. {{US trademark|74013898|74013898}} related to usage of the term. The United States Patent and Trademark Office issued the {{US trademark|74013898|"trademark registration"}} September 4, 1990, to Texas A&M. Four additional Trademark claims related to the "12th Man" term were also filed and granted at later dates by Texas A&M University (See U.S. Ser. Nos. {{US trademark|74560726|74560726}}, {{US trademark|76671314|76671314}}, {{US trademark|85977835|85977835}} and {{US trademark|85851199|85851199}}), the first three of which have achieved [[Trademark|Incontestable Status]]{{technical statement|reason=term not in linked article|date=February 2016}} as a result of its section 15 affidavit with the Patent and Trademark Office. According to former Texas A&M Athletic Director Bill Byrne, he contacted the Chicago Bears and Buffalo Bills about halting their "12th Man" themes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Seahawks' "12th Man" angers A&M|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nfl&id=2309646|website=ESPN.com|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=2 June 2014|date=28 January 2006}}</ref> Byrne stated that, "they responded quickly with our requests to stop using our Twelfth Man trademark."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moghe|first1=Sonia|title=Trademarking your territory|url=http://www.thebatt.com/2.8485/trademarking-your-territory-1.1196013#.Ux8nc_lkTzg|archiveurl=http://msl1.mit.edu/furdlog/docs/2006-01-27_thebatt_12th_man.pdf|archivedate=27 January 2006|date=27 January 2006}}</ref> Texas A&M sent requests to stop using the phrase to the Seattle Seahawks in both 2004 and 2005. The Seahawks did not respond to the requests.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/seahawks/2006-01-30-12th-man-order_x.htm | work=USA Today | title=Texas A&M seeks restraining order over '12th man' | date=January 31, 2006}}</ref>
In January 2006, Texas A&M filed a trademark infringement lawsuit against the [[Seattle Seahawks]] and in May 2006, the dispute was settled out of court. Neither side admitted any fault or liability. In the agreement, the Seahawks licensed the phrase in exchange for $100,000, along with public acknowledgement as to Texas A&M's ownership rights of the phrase, and an additional annual fee.<ref>{{cite web|title='12th Man' for everyone: Seattle, A&M resolve dispute|publisher=ESPN|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2437992|date=May 8, 2006|accessdate=July 26, 2007}}</ref> The compensation amounted to $5,000 per year.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|last=Jessop|first=Alicia|title=Texas A&M Stands To Earn More In Upcoming 12th Man Trademark Licensing Negotiations As Seahawks' Exposure Rises|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/aliciajessop/2014/01/31/texas-am-stands-to-earn-more-in-upcoming-12th-man-trademark-licensing-negotiations-as-seahawks-exposure-rises/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=February 17, 2014|date=January 31, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodbullhunting.com/2014/1/19/5271954/12th-man-trademark-licensing-agreement-texas-am-aggies-seattle-seahawks|title="12th Man" - Inside Texas A&M's License Agreement with the Seattle Seahawks|author=Brandon Hamburg|date=January 19, 2014|work=Good Bull Hunting}}</ref> The agreement, which expired in 2016, limited the Seahawks' usage to seven western states and forbid them from selling any "12th Man" merchandise.<ref name=Forbes /> In August 2015, the Seahawks shifted towards calling their fans the "12s", and replaced their "Home of the 12th Man" stadium sign with a new "Home of the 12s" sign.<ref>{{cite web |last=Daniels |first=Chris |title=CenturyLink Field no longer 'Home of the 12th Man' |url=http://www.king5.com/story/sports/nfl/seahawks/2015/08/14/12th-man-seahawks-texasam/31753553/ |publisher=[[KING-TV|KING 5 News]] |date=August 14, 2015 |accessdate=August 15, 2015}}</ref>
On November 12, 2015, Texas A&M filed suit against the Indianapolis Colts after repeated cease and desist requests were ignored by the NFL club.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rovell|first=Darren |title=Texas A&M says Colts ignoring calls to stop use of '12th Man' |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/14113722/texas-aggies-sue-indianapolis-colts-use-12th-man-trademark |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=November 12, 2015 |accessdate=November 12, 2015}}</ref> On February 17, 2016, the lawsuit was settled with the Colts agreeing to remove the phrase from their Ring of Honor and to immediately cease all other uses of the trademarked phrase.<ref name="indystar.com"/>
In August 2016, the Seahawks agreed to a new five year trademark licensing agreement with Texas A&M. As part of the agreement, the Seahawks agreed to pay Texas A&M $140,000 for limited rights to use the trademarked term. This agreement, like the previous agreement, prohibits the Seahawks from using the "12th Man" term on any merchandise. The new agreement, however, also prohibits Seattle from using the term on social media, nor are they allowed to use the term on any signage within their stadium, including their Ring of Honor.<ref name="espn.com"/>
==See also== * [[Sixth man]] * [[Sixth man (fans)]]

revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1922 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==American football== '''NFL championship''' * [[1922 Canton Bulldogs season|Canton Bulldogs]] wins the APFA (NFL) title with a record of 10 wins, 0 losses and 2 ties.
'''College championship''' * [[Cornell Big Red football|Cornell Big Red]] – [[college football]] national championship
'''Events''' * 24 June — the American Professional Football Association renames itself as the [[National Football League]].
==Association football== '''England''' * [[1921–22 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 57 points, [[Tottenham Hotspur]] 51, [[Burnley FC|Burnley]] 49, [[Cardiff City]] 48, [[Aston Villa]] 47, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 47 * [[1922 FA Cup final|FA Cup final]] – [[Huddersfield Town]] 1–0 [[Preston North End]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – no decision after [[Hamburger SV]] and [[1. FC Nürnberg]] played two drawn games '''Russia''' * [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]], as known well for former [[Soviet Union]], officially founded on April 18.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Soccer around the World|last=Parrish|first=Charles|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2014|isbn=9781610693035|location=|pages=}}</ref>
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== '''Monaco''' * [[1922 Women's World Games|second Women's Olympiad]] in Monte Carlo '''France''' * the [[1922 Women's World Games|first Women's World Games]], Paris
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1922 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * 14 October – [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] wins the 26th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership, defeating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 11.13 (79) to 9.14 (68) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) in the [[1922 VFL Grand Final]]. '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''' * 30 September – [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 9.7 (61) defeat [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]] 2.16 (28) to win their fifteenth SAFL premiership. * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Robert Barnes (footballer)|Robert Barnes]] (West Adelaide) '''[[1922 WAFL season|West Australian Football League]]''' * 23 September – [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 7.13 (55) beat [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] 5.9 (39) to win their fourth successive premiership * [[Sandover Medal]] won by [[Harold Boyd (footballer, born 1900)|Harold Boyd]] (West Perth)
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[IK Sirius]] 3-2 [[Västerås SK Bandy|Västerås SK]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 4–8 October — [[1922 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (NL) defeats [[1922 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] (AL) to win the [[1922 World Series]] by 4 games to 0 with one tie '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Chicago American Giants]] win their third consecutive [[Negro National League (the first)|Negro National League]] pennant.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 10 July — [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] regains the [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship when he defeats [[Johnny Buff]] with a 14th-round technical knockout in [[New York City|New York]] * 24 September — [[Battling Siki]] captures the [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship when he knocks out [[Georges Carpentier]] in the 6th round in [[Paris]]. * 1 November — [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]], one of the greatest boxing champions, wins his first world title when he defeats [[World Welterweight Champion]] [[Jack Britton]] over 15 rounds in [[New York City|New York]] '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Georges Carpentier]] → [[Battling Siki]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Wilson (boxer)|Johnny Wilson]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Britton]] → [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Buff]] → [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[10th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – [[Queen's University]] 13–1 [[Edmonton Elks]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] recovers the [[County Championship]] to begin a run of four successive titles. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Buckinghamshire County Cricket Club|Buckinghamshire]] * Most runs – [[C. A. G. Russell|Jack Russell]] 2575 @ 54.78 (HS 172) * Most wickets – [[Charlie Parker (cricketer)|Charlie Parker]] 206 @ 13.16 (BB 9–36) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Arthur Carr (cricketer)|Arthur Carr]], [[Tich Freeman]], [[Charlie Parker (cricketer)|Charlie Parker]], [[C. A. G. Russell|Jack Russell]], [[Andy Sandham]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Frank O'Keeffe]] 708 @ 118.00 (HS 180) * Most wickets – [[Ted McDonald]] 28 @ 21.50 (BB 8–84) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – undecided '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Firmin Lambot]] (Belgium) wins the 16th [[1921 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Events''' * 17 September — [[Netherlands|Dutch]] cyclist [[Piet Moeskops]] becomes World Champion in the [[UCI Track Cycling World Championships - Men's Sprint]].
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] * [[US Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Gene Sarazen]] * [[PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Gene Sarazen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Ernest Holderness]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Jess Sweetser]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Grand National]] – Music Hall * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Silver Urn]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[St Louis (horse)|St Louis]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Captain Cuttle]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Pogrom (horse)|Pogrom]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Royal Lancer]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – King Ingoda '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – South Shore '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Ksar (horse)|Ksar]] (second successive victory) '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Halston * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Spike Island '''USA''' * [[1921 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Morvich * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Pillory * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Pillory
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * 17–28 March — [[1921–22 Toronto St. Patricks season|Toronto St. Pats]] defeats [[Vancouver Millionaires]] in the [[1922 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1922 in motorsport|List of 1922 motorsport champions}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 1 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 74th [[The Boat Race 1922|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Rochdale Hornets]] 10–9 [[Hull F.C.]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], Leeds * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]] 7–5 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] 11–3 [[Dewsbury Rams|Dewsbury]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[North Sydney Bears|North Sydney]] 35–3 [[Glebe (rugby league team)|Glebe]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 35th [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1922 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Harald Strøm]] (Norway)
==[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]== '''Events''' * [[Johnny Weissmuller]] swims the 100 metres freestyle in 58.6 seconds to create a world record and break the "minute barrier"
==[[Tennis]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] is held. '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[James Anderson (tennis)|James Anderson]] (Australia) defeats [[Gerald Patterson]] (Australia) 6–0 3–6 3–6 6–3 6–2 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Margaret Molesworth]] (Australia) defeats [[Esna Boyd Robertson]] (Australia) 6–3 10–8 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Gerald Patterson]] (Australia) defeats [[Randolph Lycett]] (Great Britain) 6–3 6–4 6–2 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) 6–2 6–0 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Henri Cochet]] (France) defeats [[Jean Samazeuilh]] (France) 8–6 6–3 7–5 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Suzanne Lenglen]] (France) defeats [[Germaine Golding]] (France) 6–4 6–2 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 4–6 3–6 6–2 6–3 6–4 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) 6–3 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1922 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 4–1 {{davis|Australasia}} at [[West Side Tennis Club]] (grass) [[New York City]], [[United States]]
==Water skiing== '''Events''' * [[Water skiing]] invented in [[Lake City, Minnesota]] by [[Ralph Samuelson]]

{{Infobox sport tournament |year = 2012 |name = All-American Strongman Challenge |image = All American Strongman Challenge Logo.jpg |caption = The logo of 2010 Gaspari Nutrition All-American Strongman Challenge |location = [[Los Angeles, California]] |establishment = 2005 |format = Multi-event competition |purse = |month_played = January |current_champion = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Mike Burke (strongman)|Mike Burke]] }} The '''All-American Strongman Challenge''' is a leading competition in [[strength athletics]] that takes place within the annual Californian FitExpo. Although [[North America]] has a number of prestigious strongman events determining the "Strongest Man in America", the "Strongest Man in Canada" and the "Strongest Man in North America", the All-American Strongman Challenge has added kudos because it is open to entrants from overseas with the potential to bring in leading international competitors as well. It is notable for the calibre of entrants it has attracted, with many [[World's Strongest Man]] finalists being represented. == FitExpo 2005 == '''Dates:''' 19, 20 February 2005
'''Location:''' [[Pasadena, California|Pasadena]] ([[California]]) {{flagicon|USA}} '''Contest Report:'''[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2005/Feb/Brian_Schoonveld_Smashes_World_Record_in_the_IronMind_Apollons_Axle_at_the_FitExpo_Jesse_Marunde_is_in_the_Lead.html ''Brian_Schoonveld_Smashes_World_Record_in_the_IronMind_Apollons_Axle_at_the_FitExpo_Jesse_Marunde_is_in_the_Lead'' by Randall J. Strossen of Ironmind]
'''Location:''' Los Angeles Convention Center, [[Los Angeles]] ([[California]]) {{flagicon|USA}} '''Sponsor:'''Gaspari Nutrition '''Report''' : The All-American Strongman Challenge, once again at the bodybuilding.com/Los Angeles FitExpo, was in 2010 a truly international field. Organised by [[Odd Haugen]], the event drew its largest crowd ever. In addition to the title and prize money, the winner was guaranteed an invitation to the [[Arnold Strongman Classic]] contest, as well as one to the [[Mohegan Sun Grand Prix]]. ===Results=== {| class="wikitable" !Position !Name !Points |- | 1. || [[Nick Best]] || 70 |- | 2. || [[Mark Felix]] || 64 |- | 3. || [[Louis-Philippe Jean]] || 59 |- | 4. || [[Josh Thigpen]] || 56.0 |- | 5. || [[Terry Hollands]] || 53.5 |- | 6. || [[Robert Szczepanski]] || 50.0 |- | 7. || [[Marshall White]] || 49.5 |- | 8. || [[David Ostlund]] || 42.0 |- | 9. || [[Karl Gillingham]] || 41.5 |- | 10. || [[Andy Vincent]] || 39.5 |- | 11. || [[Jerry Pritchett]] || 36 |- | 12. || [[Corey St. Clair]] || 26 |- | 13. || [[David Hansen (strongman)|David Hansen]] || 22 |- | 14. || [[Odd Haugen]] || 15 |} == All-American Strongman Challenge 2011 == '''Dates:''' 29, 30 January 2011[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2011/Jan/Terry_Hollands_Wins_at_the_FitExpo_Strongman-Nick_Best_is_Second.html Terry Hollands Wins at the FitExpo Strongman . . . Nick Best is Second] '''Location:''' Los Angeles Convention Center, [[Los Angeles]] ([[California]]) {{flagicon|USA}} '''Sponsor:'''Gaspari Nutrition The All-American Strongman Challenge was once again hosted by [[Odd Haugen]] at the bodybuilding.com/Los Angeles FitExpo. The event included a separate grip contest titled "Vice Grip Viking Challenge" which was won by [[Mark Felix]] along with $2,500 in prize money.[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2011/Jan/Grip_Contest_at_FitExpo_Crushes_The_Competition.html Grip Contest at FitExpo Crushes The Competition] The top 2 finishers of the strongman contest were guaranteed invitations to the [[Arnold Strongman Classic]] contest. ===Results=== {| class="wikitable" !Position !Name !Points |- | 1. || [[Terry Hollands]] || 125.5 |- | 2. || [[Nick Best]] || 115.5 |- | 3. || [[Mark Felix]] || 102 |- | 4. || [[Louis-Philippe Jean]] || 101.5 |- | 5. || [[Marshall White]] || 100 |- | 6. || [[Jerry Pritchett]] || 99 |- | 7. || [[Dan Harrison (strongman)|Dan Harrison]] || 88 |- | 8. || [[Jean-Francois Caron (strongman)|Jean-Francois Caron]] || 84.5 |- | 9. || [[Josh Thigpen]] || 75.5 |- | 10. || [[Warrick Brant]] || 74 |} ===Vice Grip Viking Challenge Results=== {| class="wikitable" !Position !Name !Points |- | 1. || [[Mark Felix]] || 43 $2,500 prize money |- | 2. || [[Andrew Durniat]] || 40 $1,500 prize money |- | 3. || [[Chad Woodall]] || 36 $1,000 prize money |- | 4. || [[Odd Haugen]] || 35 |- | 5. || [[Louis-Philippe Jean]] || 20.5 |- | 6. || [[Jerry Pritchett]] || 8.5 |- | 7. || [[Josh Thigpen]] || 4 |} ==All-American Strongman Challenge 2012== '''Dates:''' 28, 29 January 2012[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2012/Jan/Strongman_Mike_Burke_Wins_at_the_LA_FitExpo.html Strongman Mike Burke Wins at the LA FitExpo] '''Location:''' Los Angeles Convention Center, [[Los Angeles]] ([[California]]) '''Sponsor:'''Met-Rx The 2012 All-American Strongman Challenge was hosted by [[Odd Haugen]] at the Bodybuilding.com/Los Angeles FitExpo. The separate grip contest titled "Vice Grip Viking Challenge" returned for its second year, with [[Mark Felix]] retaining his title, along with $1,000 in prize money.[http://www.ironmind.com/ironmind/opencms/Articles/2012/Jan/Mark_Felix_Wins_the_Visegrip_Viking_Challenge.html Mark Felix Wins the Visegrip Viking Challenge] ===Results=== {| class="wikitable" !Position !Name !Points |- | 1. || [[Mike Burke (strongman)|Mike Burke]] || 47 |- | 2. || [[Stefan Solvi Petursson]] || 44.5 |- | 3. || [[Nick Best]] || 35.5 |- | 4. || [[Josh Thigpen]] || 34.5 |- | 5. || [[Vincent Urbank]] || 32 |- | 6. || [[Jerry Pritchett]] || 28.5 |- | 7. || [[Jamie Rude]] || 19.5 |- | 8. || [[Mark Felix]] || 18.5 |- | 9. || [[Joel Dircks]] || 7 |} ===Vice Grip Viking Challenge Results=== {| class="wikitable" !Position !Name !Points |- | 1. || [[Mark Felix]] || 52.5 $1,000 prize money |- | 2. || [[Mike Burke (strongman)|Mike Burke]] || 49 $600 prize money |- | 3. || [[Andrew Durniat]] || 48 $400 prize money |- | 4. || [[Odd Haugen]] || 40 |- | 5. || [[Jerry Pritchett]] || 33.5 |- | 6. || [[Josh Thigpen]] || 29.5 |- | 7. || [[Vincent Urbank]] || 28 |- | 8. || [[Joel Dircks]] || 26.5 |- | 8. || [[Daniel Reinhardt]] || 26.5 |- | 10. || [[Jon Eklund]] || 26 |- | 11. || [[Steve Schmidt (strongman)|Steve Schmidt]] || 25 |} == See also == * [[America's Strongest Man]] * [[Arnold Strongman Classic]] * [[North America's Strongest Man]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.thefitexpo.com/strongman.asp Official Portal 2010] [[Category:Strongmen competitions]] [[Category:Sports in Los Angeles]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox game | title = ''Buckaroo!'' | italic title = yes | subtitle = The saddle-stacking game with a moody mule! | image_link = | image_caption = | designer = [[Ideal Toy Company]] | illustrator = | publisher= [[Ideal Toy Company]]
[[Milton Bradley Company|Milton Bradley]] | date = {{start date and age|1970}} | players = 2+ Players | setup_time = | playing_time = | complexity = Low | strategy = Medium | random_chance = | skills = }} '''Buckaroo!''' is a [[game of skill|game of physical skill]], intended for players aged four and above. Buckaroo! is made by [[Milton Bradley Company|Milton Bradley]], a division of the toy company [[Hasbro]].[http://www.hasbro.com/en-gb/product/buckaroo-game:92774685-6D40-1014-8BF0-9EFBF894F9D4 Hasbro Buckaroo page] == Description == The game centers on an articulated plastic model of a [[mule]] named "Roo" (or "Buckaroo"). The mule begins the game standing on all four feet, with a blanket on its back. Players take turns placing various items onto the mule's back without causing the mule to buck up on its front legs, throwing off all the accumulated items (the toy has a spring mechanism that is triggered by significant vibration). The player who triggered this buck is knocked out of the game, and play resumes. The winner is the last player remaining in the game. In the (unlikely) event that a player manages to place the last item onto the mule's back without it bucking, that player is the winner. The toy has three sensitivity levels that are adjustable via a switch located on the side of the mule's body, under the blanket. The switch adjusts the location of the lever to which the blanket is attached in relation to the trigger mechanism attached to the spring.[http://www.hasbro.com/common/instruct/buckaroo.pdf Rules for playing Buckaroo!] === Items === The items which players must place on the mule's back are (variations in names from 2007 UK version in parentheses): {{colbegin}} * a [[bedroll]] * a [[Canteen (bottle)|canteen]] (water bottle) * a [[cowboy hat]] * a [[crate]] ([[rifle]] box) * a [[frying pan]] * a [[guitar]] * a [[holster]] (holster with [[gun]]) * a [[lantern]] (lamp) * a [[rope]] * a [[saddle]] * a [[shovel]] * a stick of [[dynamite]] {{colend}} Of these, the saddle must be placed first. It has a number of articulation points on which the subsequent items are hung. These other items may be placed in any order. == History == It was originally released in 1970 by [[Ideal Toy Company]] using a white mule, this has now been replaced with a brown one. ===Criticism=== In 2006, Buckaroo! was considered dangerous, due to the objects getting flung off the mule when the spring is triggered. On ''[[Good Morning America]]'' and [[CTV News]], it was mentioned that an object had hit a child in the eye, in [[North Carolina]], causing the 8-year-old boy to have surgery. The game was discontinued until 2008 when the instructions were adjusted. ==In popular culture== * Buckaroo! is a favorite game of [[Father Dougal McGuire]] in [[Ireland|Irish]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Father Ted]]''. He regularly plays the game with [[Father Ted Crilly|Ted]], despite the fact that Ted hates it and would rather play [[chess]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dCeLKp2gxsM|title=Tentacles Of Doom, Father Ted, Season 2 Episode 3|pages=334 seconds in|accessdate=13 October 2018}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090215113012/http://www.hasbro.com/shop/details.cfm?guid=92774685-6D40-1014-8BF0-9EFBF894F9D4&product_id=15991&src=endeca Hasbro's product page] * [http://www.hasbro.com/common/instruct/buckaroo.pdf Rules for playing Buckaroo!] * [http://www.hasbro.co.uk/downloads/HasbroUK_Buckaroo_Instructions.pdf UK rules - 1996 version] {{Hasbro}} [[Category:Games of physical skill]] [[Category:Milton Bradley Company games]] [[Category:1970s toys]] [[Category:Games and sports introduced in 1970]]

football|football]]}} {{MedalCompetition | [[Asian Games]]}} {{MedalBronze | [[2002 Asian Games|2002 Busan]] | [[Football at the 2002 Asian Games|Team]]}} }} {{Infobox Korean name|hangul=최성국|hanja=崔成國|rr=Choe Seong-Guk|mr=Ch'oe Sŏngguk}} '''Choi Sung-Kuk''' (born 8 February 1983) is a former [[South Korea]]n footballer who played the [[Forward (association football)|forward]] position. He was part of the [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Olympic]] football team, who finished second in Group A, making it through to the next round, before being defeated by silver medal winners [[Paraguay]]. He was also capped for South Korean U-20 team at [[2003 FIFA World Youth Championship]]. A member of Korea's squad for the [[2007 AFC Asian Cup]], he scored a goal in the opening match against Saudi Arabia. ==Club career== ===Ulsan=== Choi joined [[Ulsan Hyundai]], the [[K-League]] giant in 2003. Ulsan placed second in the league that season. In 2005, he was loaned out to [[J1 League]] side [[Kashiwa Reysol]], but after a 5-month disappointing spell, he returned to Ulsan. Following his return, Ulsan won the league that year. Choi also became the top scorer for the [[Hauzen Cup]], which is the Korean League Cup. It seemed definite that Choi would become Ulsan's icon, but he moved to [[Seongnam Ilhwa Chunma]], which made many Ulsan supporters extremely angry at the board. ===Seongnam=== Choi helped Seongnam become the runner-up that season. However, after his disappointing 2008 season Choi announced he would join the army in 2009, which angered many Seongnam fans. He moved to [[Gwangju Sangmu FC|Gwangju Sangmu]], the army team at the beginning of the 2009 season. There, his partnership with [[Kim Myung-Joong]] was the core of Gwangju's surprising performance. In late 2010, he returned to Seongnam and participated in the [[2010 FIFA Club World Cup]]. He scored in the quarterfinal against [[United Arab Emirates]] side [[Al Wahda S.C.C.|Al-Wahda]]. ===Suwon=== Choi moved to [[Suwon Samsung Bluewings]] prior to the 2011 season. ;[[2011 South Korean football betting scandal|Match-fixing scandal in June 2011]] Choi was implicated in a match-fixing scandal while playing for the military team, Sangmu. He denied his involvement when media reports raised the allegations about throwing matches, but soon admitted it as the scandal deepened. Consequently, he was tentatively dropped from his team. It was officially announced in August 2011 that he would not be able to play in the [[Korea Republic football league system|all league systems in South Korea]] permanently. ===Rabotnički=== On 16 January 2012, it was announced that Choi would join [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonian]] side [[FK Rabotnički]][http://www.macedonianfootball.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4125:choi-sung-kuk-arrived-at-rabotnicki&catid=1:domestic&Itemid=63 Choi Sung-Kuk arrived at Rabotnicki] at MacedonianFootball.com, 16 January 2012 It was to be his first club in Europe of his career. However, his move fell through after the [[Football Federation of Macedonia]] rejected the player's registration after K-League revealed Choi had been banned from playing professional football in any league by FIFA.{{cite news|title=Fifa bans South Korea's Choi Sung-Kuk in wake of match-fixing scandal|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2557/news/2012/03/16/2970590/fifa-bans-south-koreas-choi-sung-kuk-in-wake-of-match-fixing|publisher=Goal.com|date=16 March 2012|accessdate=16 April 2012}} As of 16 March 2012, Choi Sung-Kuk future football career is in doubt. ==Club statistics== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! colspan=3 | Club performance ! colspan=2 | League ! colspan=2 | Cup ! colspan=2 | League Cup ! colspan=2 | Continental ! colspan=2 | Total |- ! Season !! Club !! League ! Apps !! Goals ! Apps !! Goals ! Apps !! Goals ! Apps !! Goals ! Apps !! revision.text:
'''Dual Box''' or '''DualBox''' is the trademark name for the patented tubular sidewall [[inline skate|inline skating frame]], which employs the mechanical properties of the tubular to optimize the performance of a frame or chassis that secures the wheels on an inline skate (a critical component of high performance skates).
Designed in 1999 by [[Netherlands|Dutch]] Design Engineer [[Diederik Hol]] at [[Mogema]], the Dual Box design was devised to optimize the elastic properties of inline skate frames (which the skater interprets as stiffness and feel, and contribute greatly to ride quality and power transmission) via the properties of the tubular sidewalls to enhance rigidity.
The Dual Box design successfully eliminates the need for horizontal cross-bracing in inline skate frames, and provided progressive flexural feel for the skater rather than the isolated areas of varying stiffness which were inherent to many, more traditional double-void [[extrusion]] frames.
Through a product partnership with the Mogema company, the [[Rollerblade]] professional racing team debuted the Dual Box frame to the world in 2001 after which time team athletes rode Dual Box frames across the finish line first in numerous Swiss Inline Cup, [[World Inline Cup]] and World Championship events. During this time the Dual Box became one of the most recognized and successful frame designs in [[Inline speed skating|speed skating]], with 45 athletes winning their Gold, Silver and Bronze medals at the 2001 World Speed Skating Championship on the frames.
Since 2003, the Rollerblade company has produced Dual Box frames under [[licence]] from Mogema and has specified Dual Box technology in their high-performance skate product lines. Today, following the dissolution of Mogema in 2006, Dual Box designer Diederik Hol's own company CadoMotus produces its own skating frames based on an evolution of the Dual Box tubular sidewall.
==External links== * [http://www.cadomotus.com/ CadoMotus website] * [http://www.swiss-inline-cup.ch/ Swiss Inline Cup (in German)] * [http://www.world-inline-cup.com/ World Cup of Inline Racing] * [http://www.rollersports.org/ Fédération Internationale de Roller Sports]
[[Category:Roller skating equipment]] [[Category:Roller skates]] [[Category:Dutch inventions]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Edip Buran Arena
Edip Buran Spor Salonu | former names = Yenişehir Belediyesi Sports Hall (Yenişehir Belediyesi Spor Salonu) | image = | location = [[Yenişehir, Mersin|Yenişehir]], [[Mersin]], [[Turkey]] |coordinates = {{coord|36|47|21|N|34|36|43|E|type:landmark_scale:100000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = {{start date and age|1971}} | renovated = {{start date and age|2013}} | owner = Youth Services and Sports Directoriate of Mersin | operator = | construction_cost = | former_names = | tenants = {{ubl|[[Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi S.K.|Mersin BB men's basketball team]] |[[Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi (women's basketball)|Mersin BB women's basketball team]] }} | seating_capacity = 1,750 |Official_website = }} The '''Edip Buran Arena''' ({{lang-tr|Edip Buran Spor Salonu}}), formerly '''Yenişehir Belediyesi Sports Hall''' ({{lang-tr|Yenişehir Belidyesi Spor Salonu}}), is a multi-sport [[indoor arena]] at [[Yenişehir, Mersin|Yenişehir]] district of [[Mersin]], [[Turkey]]. Built in 1971, it is owned by the Youth Services and Sports Directoriate of Mersin. The sports hall has a seating capacity of 1,750.{{cite news |url=http://spor.haberturk.com/basketbol/haber/679354-beko-basketbol-ligi-46-yasina-giriyor |newspaper=[[Habertürk]] |title=Beko Basketbol Ligi 46 yaşına giriyor! |date=2011-10-14 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-06-22 }} It was renovated for the [[2013 Mediterranean Games]],{{cite web|url=http://mersin.gsb.gov.tr/Sayfalar/tesisDetay.aspx?DT=25 |publisher=Mersin Gençlik Hizmetleri ve Spor İl Müdürlüğü |title=Tesislerimiz-Edip Buran Spor Salonu |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-06-22 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and the new sports hall went on January 20, 2013 in service.{{cite news|url=http://www.sporbox.net/tr/s_detay.asp?id=16166 |newspaper=Spor Box |title=Edip Buran Spor Salonu Yenilendi |date=2013-01-22 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224911/http://www.sporbox.net/tr/s_detay.asp?id=16166 |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }} The venue is suitable for events of basketball, fencing, gymnastics, handball, judo, karate, table tennis, teakwondo, volleyball, wrestling etc. With the promotion of [[Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi S.K.|Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi men's basketball team]]'s to [[Turkish Basketball League]] in the 2005-06 season, the sports hall became a basketball league venue.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/basketbol/23023691.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] Spor |title=Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi 57 - 73 İstanbul Üniversitesi |date=2013-04-11 |language=|accessdate=2013-07-10 }} The venue is also home to the [[Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi (women's basketball)|women's side of the Mersin Büyükşehir Belediyesi S.K.]], which plays in the [[Turkish Women's Basketball League]] (TKBL).{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/basketbol/22883342.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] Spor |title=Akdeniz derbisi Mersin'in |date=2013-03-23 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-07-10 }} ==Major events== [[Turkey national handball team]] played their home match against [[Portugal national handball team|Portugal]] in the [[2013 World Men's Handball Championship – European qualification]] at the venue on January 8, 2012.{{cite news|url=http://avrupa.hurriyet.com.tr/haberler/spor/1099238/portekize-maglup-olduk |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130710082410/http://avrupa.hurriyet.com.tr/haberler/spor/1099238/portekize-maglup-olduk |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-07-10 |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] Avrupa |title=Portekiz'e 34-26 mağlup olduk |date=2012-01-08 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-07-10 }} All the [[2014 European Men's Handball Championship qualification#Group 4|Group 4 matches of the 2014 European Men's Handball Championship qualification]] were played in the arena from June 8 to 10, 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/digersporlar/20697503.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] Spor |title=A Milliler'in rakipleri belli oldu |date=2012-06-05 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-07-10 }} Turkey national team's home match against [[France national handball team |France]] in the Qualification Phase 2 of the same tournament took place in the sports hall on November 4, 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/spor/digersporlar/21851600.asp |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] Spor |title=Hentbolda Fransa'ya boyun eğdik |date=2012-11-04 |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-07-10 }} During the 2013 Mediterranean Games, the arena hosted [[Taekwondo at the 2013 Mediterranean Games|taekwondo]] competitions on June 21-23 and [[Karate at the 2013 Mediterranean Games|karate]] competitions between 28 June and 29 June while the training activities of the related sports branches took place also at the sports hall.{{cite web |url=http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/6747/Edip-Buran-Spor-Salonu |publisher=Mersin 2013 |title=Edip Buran Spor Salonu |language=Turkish |accessdate=2013-06-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611021454/http://www.mersin2013.gov.tr/detay/6747/Edip-Buran-Spor-Salonu |archivedate=2013-06-11 |df= }} ==References==
