revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox college coach | name = Mike Leach | image = LeachMike092212-18.JPG | alt = | caption = Leach during a 2012 Washington State football game | sport = [[American football|Football]] | current_title = Head Coach | current_team = Washington State Cougars | current_conference = Pac-12 | current_record = 48–40 | contract = $3,750,000 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|3|9}} | birth_place = [[Susanville, California]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] (1983) | coach_years1 = 1987 | coach_team1 = [[Cal Poly Mustangs football|Cal Poly]] (OL) | coach_years2 = 1988 | coach_team2 = [[College of the Desert]] (LB) | coach_years3 = 1989 | coach_team3 = [[American Football Association of Finland|Pori Bears]] | coach_years4 = 1989–1991 | coach_team4 = [[Iowa Wesleyan Tigers football|Iowa Wesleyan]] ([[Offensive coordinator|OC]]/OL) | coach_years5 = 1992–1993 | coach_team5 = [[Valdosta State Blazers football|Valdosta State]] (OC/WR/QB) | coach_years6 = 1994–1996 | coach_team6 = Valdosta State (OC/OL) | coach_years7 = 1997–1998 | coach_team7 = [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]] (OC/QB) | coach_years8 = 1999 | coach_team8 = [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] (OC/QB) | coach_years9 = 2000–2009 | coach_team9 = [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]] | coach_years10 = 2012–present | coach_team10 = [[Washington State Cougars football|Washington State]] | overall_record = 132–83 | bowl_record = 6–7 | tournament_record = | championships = 1 [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12 South Division]] (2008)
1 | awards = [[George Munger Award]] (2008)
[[Woody Hayes Trophy]] (2008)
[[Big 12 Conference football individual awards#Coach of the Year|Big 12 Coach of the Year]] (2008)
[[Pac-12 Conference football individual awards|Pac-12 Coach of the Year]] (2015) | coaching_records = }} '''Michael Charles Leach''' (born March 9, 1961) is an American [[college football]] coach. He is the head coach of the [[Washington State Cougars football]] team. Previously, he was [[head coach]] of the [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football]] team, leading the Red Raiders to winning seasons in every year of his tenure. ==Personal life== Born to Frank and Sandra Leach{{cite web|url=http://www.nndb.com/people/573/000166075/|title=Mike Leach}} in [[Susanville, California]], Mike Leach claims [[Cody, Wyoming]], as his hometown.{{cite web|url=http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile&friendid=38792761|title=Mike Leach – MySpace profile |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119174116/http://profile.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=user.viewprofile |archivedate=November 19, 2008|df=}} He graduated from Cody High School before studying at [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU), where he closely followed the exploits of the [[BYU Cougars football]] team. The Cougars, guided by head coach [[LaVell Edwards]] and offensive coordinator [[Norm Chow]], played a pass-oriented offense, which was unique to college football at that time. Leach graduated in 1983 with a bachelor's degree in American studies.[http://www.footballscoop.com/archives/coach-august.htm Coach of the Month] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060531234534/http://www.footballscoop.com/archives/coach-august.htm |date=May 31, 2006 }} In 1986, Leach earned a [[Juris Doctor]] (J.D.) from [[Pepperdine University School of Law]]. Leach is also one of the most prominent graduates of the [[United States Sports Academy]], from which he earned a Master's of Sports Science in Sports Coaching in 1988. Leach is married with four children. He was raised a member of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]. Leach is atypical among [[NCAA Division I]] head football coaches in that he did not play [[American football|football]] at the college level. He is one of only four such coaches along with [[Paul Johnson (American football coach)|Paul Johnson]] at [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]], [[David Cutcliffe]] at [[Duke Blue Devils football|Duke]], and [[Chad Morris]] at [[Arkansas Razorbacks football|Arkansas]].{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} Famous among fans for his fascination with 18th-century [[Golden Age of Piracy|pirates]] such as [[Edward Teach|Blackbeard]] and [[Calico Jack]], Leach has lectured his players on the history of pirates, and told them before games to "swing their swords." His office has been described as a museum of pirate paraphernalia.{{cite web |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=schlabach_mark&id=3385098|title=Eccentric Leach ready to lead Red Raiders to ultimate treasure|author=Mark Schlabach|date=May 7, 2008|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=December 31, 2009}} In particular, Leach admires the [[teamwork]] exhibited by pirates: {{quote|Pirates function as a team. There were a lot of castes and classes in England at the time. But with pirates, it didn't matter if you were black, white, rich or poor. The object was to get a treasure. If the captain did a bad job, you could just overthrow him.|4=Mike Leach|5=}} Leach's affinity for pirates came to bear in a cameo he made on the TV series ''[[Friday Night Lights (TV series)|Friday Night Lights]]''. In the show's fourth season, he portrays a "random loon" at a gas station who implores a despondent coach [[Eric Taylor (Friday Night Lights)|Eric Taylor]] to "swing your sword" and "find your inner pirate."{{cite web|url=http://www.grantland.com/blog/hollywood-prospectus/post/_/id/43652/the-script-for-the-friday-night-lights-movie-is-almost-done-will-be-about-texas-tech%E2%80%99s-mike-leach |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323194629/http://www.grantland.com/blog/hollywood-prospectus/post/_/id/43652/the-script-for-the-friday-night-lights-movie-is-almost-done-will-be-about-texas-tech%E2%80%99s-mike-leach |archivedate=March 23, 2012}} Leach spends time during each off-season learning as much as he can about various things that interest him. Aside from pirates, he has researched topics such as [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] leader [[Geronimo]], American pioneer [[Daniel Boone]], [[grizzly bear]]s, [[chimpanzee]]s, [[whale]]s, and American artist [[Jackson Pollock]]. ==Coaching career== ===Offensive scheme=== Leach is known for building potent offenses, directing passing-oriented teams that have broken school and NCAA records at [[Valdosta State Blazers football|Valdosta State]] and [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]] where he was offensive coordinator under [[Hal Mumme]], developing their "[[Air raid offense|Air Raid Offense]]",{{cite news |url=http://www.newsok.com/ou-football-a-look-at-tts-genius/article/3322193|title=OU football: A look at TT's 'genius'|publisher=The Oklahoman|accessdate=November 15, 2008|date=November 15, 2008|authorlink=Jake Trotter|author=Trotter, Jake}} at [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] under head coach [[Bob Stoops]],{{cite news|url=http://www.newsok.com/tech-unmasked/article/3324171?custom_click=lead_story_title|title=OU football: Tech unmasked?|work=The Oklahoman|accessdate=November 22, 2008|date=November 22, 2008 |author=Trotter, Jake|authorlink=Jake Trotter}} and [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]], where he became head coach in 2000. Leach's [[spread offense]] relies heavily on passing and he has seen several of his quarterbacks post NCAA records. At Kentucky he tutored prospect [[Tim Couch]] into a No. 1 [[NFL draft]] pick. At Oklahoma, [[Josh Heupel]] became an NFL draft pick following a year under Leach's tutelage. Leach's tenure at Texas Tech produced most of the Red Raiders' [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football statistical leaders|school leaders]] in passing and receiving. ===Texas Tech=== {{main|Texas Tech Red Raiders football}} The Leach-coached Red Raiders' best finishes came with three nine-win seasons in 2002, 2005, and [[2007 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|2007]] and an 11-win season in 2008. In 2002, Tech swept its in-state conference rivals [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor]], [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]], and [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M]] for the first time since 1997 and then defeated [[Clemson Tigers|Clemson]], 55–15, in the [[Champs Sports Bowl|Tangerine Bowl]]. It was the Red Raiders' first postseason win since 1995 when they beat the [[Air Force Falcons football|Air Force Falcons]] in the [[Insight Bowl|Copper Bowl]]. In 2005, the Red Raiders opened their season with a 6–0 record, their best start since 1998. Leach built a strong passing offense at Tech, where the Red Raiders led the NCAA in passing yardage for four years in a row. He inserted [[Kliff Kingsbury]] at quarterback for three years. Kingsbury broke the NCAA records for completions in a career. Kingsbury was succeeded at the position by [[B. J. Symons]], who produced the most passing yards in a season in NCAA history. [[Sonny Cumbie]] followed, leading the Red Raiders to an upset of the then-4th ranked [[California Golden Bears football|California]] in the [[Holiday Bowl]]. [[Cody Hodges]] succeeded Cumbie, and subsequently lead the NCAA in passing. [[Graham Harrell]], the first non-senior starting QB since Kingsbury, struggled early in the 2006 season. However, he showed steady improvement beginning with the game against [[Iowa State Cyclones football|Iowa State]] and ended the season with a record-setting comeback victory over the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota Golden Gophers]]. Harrell also set NCAA records for passes completed in a season and career amongst others. [[Image:Mike-Leach-Hon-Capt-Holiday-Bowl-Dec-27-04.jpg|thumb|Leach, shown on the left, made a U.S. Navy air traffic controller an honorary team captain for the [[2004 Holiday Bowl]]]] Under Mike Leach, Texas Tech was known for its high-scoring offense and come-from-behind victories. A 70–35 win over [[TCU Horned Frogs football|TCU]] in 2004 began with TCU leading 21–0 with eight minutes remaining in the second quarter. Before Tech's scoring drives started, a TCU defensive back was caught mouthing into a TV camera, "They aren't going to score." Later in the season, Texas Tech beat [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]], 70–10, forcing the Cornhuskers to give up more points in a single game than they had before in their 114-year history. In 2005, the Red Raiders were losing to [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State]], 13–10, late in the second quarter but won the game 59–20. Also in 2005, Tech had a halftime lead of 14–10 over Texas A&M. By the end of the game, they increased the margin to 56–17. It was the Aggies' worst loss to the Red Raiders in the 64-year-old series.{{cite news|last=Lewis |first=Michael |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/04/magazine/04coach.html?ei=5090&en=c9f46201dc95f91d&ex=1291352400&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss&pagewanted=all |title=Coach Leach Goes Deep, Very Deep – New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=December 4, 2005 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}} Mike Leach was chosen to coach the South team during the 2007 inaugural Inta Juice [[North-South All-Star Classic]] game. At the end of the 2008 season, Leach was 76–39 with the Red Raiders, including 7–2 against the Texas A&M Aggies and 2–7 against the Texas Longhorns.Mack Brown Football.com With a 5–4 record, he is the all-time winningest coach in postseason play in Tech football history. Leach was one of only sixteen active college football coaches who had never had a losing season after he left Texas Tech. This was followed by a 3–9 season in his seminal year with Washington State. Of those, he is among nine who have been a head coach for at least five seasons.{{cite web |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/090307/col_090307027.shtml |title=Texas Tech-SMU game facts 09/03/07 |publisher=LubbockOnline.com |date=September 3, 2007 |accessdate=October 12, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222062948/http://lubbockonline.com/stories/090307/col_090307027.shtml |archive-date=February 22, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} In February 2009, Leach signed a three-year contract extension with Texas Tech that would pay him at least $2.5 million per year if he stayed in place through 2013. Leach's guaranteed compensation would have been $1.6 million in 2006, $1.65 million in 2007, $1.75 million in 2008, $1.85 million in 2009 and $2.15 million in 2010.[http://www.redraiders.com/stories/081206/foo_081206014.shtml ''The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal'': Leach to become $2 million man] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019171422/http://www.redraiders.com/stories/081206/foo_081206014.shtml |date=October 19, 2007 }} ====2007 Texas game controversy==== During his post-game [[press conference]] after the [[2007 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team#Texas|2007 game against Texas]], Leach used most of his time to rail against the officiating crew for what he felt were bad calls.{{cite news|url=http://www.lubbockonline.net/blogs/RR_Don/index.php?entry=entry071110-233952 |title=More on Leach's Rail Against Officials |work=LubbockOnline.net |publisher=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal |date=November 11, 2007 |accessdate=November 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723193101/http://www.lubbockonline.net/blogs/RR_Don/index.php?entry=entry071110-233952 |archivedate=July 23, 2011 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.redraiders.com/updates/postgame_update1.shtml | archive-url=https://archive.is/20070503061029/http://www.redraiders.com/updates/postgame_update1.shtml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 3, 2007 | title=Texas rolls over Tech | author=Williams, Don | work=RedRaiders.com | publisher=Lubbock Avalanche-Journal|date=November 11, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2007 }} He speculated that the officials may have favored Texas because the head official lived in Austin, because they were incompetent, or possibly because the conference wanted Texas to appear in a BCS bowl because of the increased appearance fees that such a bowl generates for the conference.{{cite news |url=http://www.statesman.com/sports/content/sports/stories/other/11/11/1111golden.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120913134145/http://www.statesman.com/sports/content/sports/stories/other/11/11/1111golden.html |dead-url=yes | archive-date=September 13, 2012 | title=Leach goes off deep end with comments on officiating – Expect Tech coach to be fined, at least. | author=Golden, Cedric | work=Austin American-Statesman |publisher=Cox Enterprises | date=November 11, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2007 }}{{cite news | url=http://www.statesman.com/sports/content/gen/ap/FBC_Texas_Tech_Leach_Rant.html |title=Texas Tech coach Leach rips officials after 59–43 loss to Texas | author=Vertuno, Jim | work=Austin American-Statesman |publisher=Cox Enterprises | date=November 11, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Jim Vertuno of the Associated Press wrote "Leach was upset officials disallowed two Tech touchdowns in the third quarter. The first was overruled when video replay clearly showed the receiver let the ball hit the ground. On the next play, a touchdown pass was negated by a holding penalty. Leach also wanted, but didn't get, a flag for roughing the quarterback."{{cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/college_football/20071110-2036-fbc-texastech-leachrant.html |title=Texas Tech coach Leach rips officials after 59–43 loss to Texas |author=Vertuno, Jim |work=SignOnSanDiego.com |publisher=San Diego Union Tribune |date=November 11, 2007 |accessdate=November 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120910221947/http://www.signonsandiego.com/sports/college_football/20071110-2036-fbc-texastech-leachrant.html |archivedate=September 10, 2012 |df= }} The ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'' reported, "[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] policy prohibits coaches from commenting publicly about game officials, so Leach's actions leave him open to reprimand, fine or worse." ESPN reported, "Big 12 official spokesman Bob Burda did not immediately respond to telephone messages seeking comment. Leach's rant will likely draw a fine from the league and possibly a suspension."{{cite news | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3104347 | title=Texas Tech coach Leach suggests Texas bias after loss | work=ESPN.com | publisher=The Disney Company |date=November 11, 2007|accessdate=November 10, 2007}} On November 13, 2007, the Big 12 fined Leach [[United States dollar|$]]10,000, the largest fine in Big 12 history.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/big12/2007-11-13-texastech-leach-fine_N.htm|title=Texas Tech coach Leach gets largest fine in league history|publisher=USA Today|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=November 13, 2007|date=November 13, 2007}} Leach also received a reprimand and was warned that further violations could result in suspension.{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/sports/5297655.html|title=Texas Tech coach Leach fined for officiating remarks |publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=November 13, 2007|date=November 13, 2007|author=Durante, Joseph}} In a Big 12 coaches' conference call that day, Leach added that he did not regret making any of the comments.{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/stories/111307dnspoleach.2039fa9d1.html|title=Texas Tech coach Mike Leach doesn't regret blasting officials|publisher=Dallas Morning News|accessdate=November 13, 2007|date=November 13, 2007|author=Brown, Chip}} Leach announced that he would appeal the fine.{{cite web |url=http://colleges.beloblog.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901094426/http://colleges.beloblog.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 1, 2006 |title=Texas college sports news | College Sports Blog | The Dallas Morning News |publisher=Colleges.beloblog.com |accessdate=October 12, 2010 }} Tech alumni and fans began raising money to aid Leach in paying the penalty in the event that it was upheld. Optionally, the proceeds raised could be used charitably.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcbd.com/Global/story.asp?S=7390918&nav=3w6y |title=NewsChannel 11 / Lubbock, TX: I Like Mike Campaign To Split Fine Funds With Area Kids |publisher=KCBD |date=November 20, 2007 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}} So, just before Christmas 2007, Leach requested that the nearly $5,000 raised to that point be spent on 400 hams to be given free to families in [[Lubbock, Texas]]. Future donations were to go to the university or athletic department.{{cite web |author=Don Williams |url=http://www.lubbockonline.com/stories/122207/red_228189932.shtml |title=I Like Mike' funds to provide 400 hams | Avalanche-Journal |publisher=Lubbockonline.com |date=December 22, 2007 |accessdate=October 12, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303185942/http://lubbockonline.com/stories/122207/red_228189932.shtml |archive-date=March 3, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Following the [[2008 Gator Bowl]], in which Virginia scored twice on penalties against Tech for intentional grounding in the end zone, Leach joked, "I felt like we had a back there on the one safety, but I don't comment on officiating. I just give out hams is what I do."[http://www.redraiders.com/stories/010208/foo_010208008.shtml Texas Tech Sports presented by The Lubbock Avalanche-Journal] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ====2008 season==== Leach, along with players [[Graham Harrell]] and [[Michael Crabtree]] were featured on the cover of the 2008 edition of ''[[Dave Campbell's Texas Football]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.kdhnews.com/news/story.aspx?s=26057 |title=Campbell picks Cove to win District 12-5A |publisher=Killeen Daily Herald |date=June 17, 2008 |accessdate=June 20, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110024723/http://www.kdhnews.com/news/story.aspx?s=26057 |archivedate=January 10, 2009}} The magazine predicted that the [[2008 Texas Tech Red Raiders football team|2008 Red Raider football team]] would be the best in [[Texas]] and would challenge for the Big 12 South title.{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/commons/persona.html?newspaperUserId=ayleein&plckPersonaPage=BlogViewPost&plckUserId=ayleein&plckPostId=Blog%3AayleeinPost%3A78f57055-6577-469a-b772-1786e6c673ba&plckController=PersonaBlog&plckScript=personaScript&plckElementId=personaDest|title=Dave Campbell's Texas Football Cover |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]]|date=June 12, 2008|accessdate=June 20, 2008}} Following a 9–0 beginning to the season, including a win over the undefeated #1 Texas Longhorns, Texas Tech Athletic Director [[Gerald Myers]] announced that the university would renegotiate Leach's contract following the conclusion of the football regular season and give him an extension.{{cite news |last=Eichelberger|first=Curtis|title=Texas Tech Says It Will Renegotiate Coach Mike Leach's Contract|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |date=November 4, 2008|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=aIaLF6lHQBjs&refer=amsports|accessdate=November 4, 2008}} The Red Raiders ended the 2008 regular season with 11 wins and 1 loss, the best in school history. The season also marked the first win over a #1 ranked team. Tech, along with Oklahoma and Texas, shared the Big 12 Conference South division title. On December 2, 2008, the [[Associated Press]] named Leach the Big 12 Coach of the Year. He received 16 votes for the honor by the agency's panel, while Texas' [[Mack Brown]] got 4.{{cite news|title=Leach named Big XII "Coach of the Year" |publisher=[[KHOU-TV]] |date=December 2, 2008 |url=http://www.khou.com/sports/college/stories/khou081202_cc_leachcoachof_theyear.24172699.html |accessdate=December 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301060023/http://www.khou.com/sports/college/stories/khou081202_cc_leachcoachof_theyear.24172699.html |archivedate=March 1, 2009 }} He won co-Coach of the Year honors from the [[Big 12]] coaches; Oklahoma's [[Bob Stoops]] received the same recognition for the same season.{{cite web |url=http://www.big12sports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=10410&ATCLID=3626465|title=2008 All-Big 12 Football Awards Announced}} The ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'' named him Coach of the Year as well.{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/120508dnspoallbig12_hp.2fc95a62.html|title=Dallas Morning News' All-Big 12 Team}} He garnered the 2008 [[George Munger Award]], which is given annually to the top college coach of the year by the [[Maxwell Football Club]].{{cite news|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/sports/story/1098052.html|title=Texas Tech's Mike Leach talks about Heisman, contract, coaching award}} After [[2008 Big 12 Conference South Division 3-way tie controversy|much controversy]] about how the tie-breaker should be handled between Texas, Oklahoma, and Texas Tech fans, the Red Raiders ended up being left out of the BCS because of a rule that states only two teams from each conference could enter BCS play per season.{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/preview?gid=200901020086&prov=ap|title=Texas Tech-Ole Miss Preview}} Oklahoma won the tie-breaker on account of their higher BCS ranking, ultimately losing to Florida in the national championship.{{cite news|url=http://espndb.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=290080201&confId=80|title=Florida rides Tebow, suffocating defense to another BCS title |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021193136/http://espndb.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=290080201&confId=80|archivedate=October 21, 2013|df=}} Texas Tech also ended up losing that year in the [[2009 Cotton Bowl Classic|Cotton Bowl]] to Ole Miss 47–34, making Texas the only team of the three to win their bowl game.{{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=290050251 |title=Longhorns squash Buckeyes' upset dreams with 26-yard score at :16}} Leach interviewed for the [[Washington Huskies football|University of Washington]] head coaching job, which was vacated by [[Tyrone Willingham]].{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/huskies/390598_husk04.html|title=Leach may get 2nd UW interview |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer | first1=Molly|last1=Yanity|date=March 12, 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/huskies/2008462306_uwfb03.html|title=Texas Tech coach Mike Leach meets with UW | work=The Seattle Times | first=Bob | last=Condotta | date=December 3, 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/huskies/390397_husk03.html|title=Cloak and rumor in Huskies search | work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |first1=Molly|last1=Yanity|date=February 12, 2008}} [[ESPN]] reported that Leach withdrew his name from the coaching search following his interview.{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3745354|title=Leach, Hill withdraw from consideration for Washington coach job}} Auburn, where [[Tommy Tuberville]] resigned,{{cite news |url=http://auburntigers.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120308aaa.html|title=Tommy Tuberville Resigns As Head Football Coach At Auburn}} had also been rumored to have contacted Leach.{{cite news |url=http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2008/12/is_auburn_looking_at_texas_tec.html|title=Unofficial Auburn contact made with camp of Texas Tech's Mike Leach, source says}} In an interview with the Associated Press, Tech quarterback Graham Harrell stated that there was a "great chance" Leach could leave. Harrell noted that Leach might leave for a newer challenge.{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2008/football/ncaa/12/05/mike-leach.ap/index.html?eref=si_ncaaf |title=Tech QB Harrell says 'great chance' Leach will leave |work=CNN |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305083242/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2008/football/ncaa/12/05/mike-leach.ap/index.html?eref=si_ncaaf |archivedate=March 5, 2009 }} After Leach withdrew his name from consideration for the Washington job, Harrell retracted his statements and believed Leach would remain the Red Raiders' coach.{{cite news |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/12/10/sports/FBC-T25-Harrell-Leach.php|title= Harrell reversed himself and said Leach was likely to stay}} Tech athletic director [[Gerald Myers]] had indicated that he would give a raise to Leach before Tech's bowl game, which he later negotiated.{{cite news|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/college_sports/story/1073669.html|title=Mike Leach visits Huskies, but Texas Tech to counter}} Leach and the university settled on a 5-year extension worth $12.7 million after months of negotiations over the clauses of the contract.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/big12/2009-02-19-texas-tech-leach_N.htm|title=Leach, Texas Tech reach agreement on new contract | work=USA Today | date=February 20, 2009 | accessdate=May 12, 2010}} ====2009 season==== On October 31, 2009, after the Red Raiders' win over Kansas, Leach tied his predecessor Spike Dykes as the all-time winningest coach in Texas Tech's 85-year football history.{{cite news|url=http://www.texastech.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/103109aad.html |title=Postgame Notes-TexasTech.com}} On November 21, 2009, Leach passed Dykes for first all-time on the school's wins list with a win over Oklahoma.{{cite news|url=http://www.texastech.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/112109aad.html|title=Texas Tech Postgame Notes|date=November 21, 2009|access-date=December 1, 2017}} ===Firing=== On December 28, 2009, Leach was suspended indefinitely by [[Texas Tech University|Texas Tech]] pending investigation of alleged inappropriate treatment of Adam James, son of former [[SMU Mustangs football|SMU]] and [[New England Patriots]] running back (and former [[ESPN]] college football analyst) [[Craig James (American football)|Craig James]]. On December 16, James suffered a [[concussion]]. He was examined the next day, and told not to practice that afternoon due to the concussion. According to a James family source, Leach ordered him to stand in the equipment room near the Raiders' practice facility. According to the ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', school officials claim they gave Leach an ultimatum to apologize to James in writing by December 28 or Leach would be suspended. His attorney, Ted Liggett, disputed the characterization of events as reported by the university and other news sources, and said that James had been treated reasonably in light of his condition.[http://www.redraiders.com/2009/12/29/leach-suspended Leach suspended after player alleges abuse]. [[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]], December 29, 2009. Leach immediately sought an injunction that would allow him to coach in the [[2010 Alamo Bowl (January)|2010 Alamo Bowl]]. However, on December 30, Texas Tech fired Leach, calling his refusal to apologize to James "a defiant act of insubordination." This was the day before Leach was reportedly owed an $800,000 tenure bonus and over $1,700,000 for contractual guaranteed income for 2009.{{cite web|url=http://collegefootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2010/06/01/report-tech-owes-leach-17-million-in-guaranteed-09-money/ |title=Report: Tech owes Leach $1.7 million in guaranteed '09 money | CollegeFootballTalk.com |publisher=Collegefootballtalk.nbcsports.com |date=June 1, 2010 |accessdate=October 12, 2010}} Texas Tech lawyers handed a termination letter to Liggett just minutes before the two sides were to appear in a Lubbock courtroom for a hearing. Liggett was also told that Leach would not be allowed to coach in the Alamo Bowl regardless of how the hearing turned out. School officials later said that other incidents had come to light during its investigation of Leach, but declined to elaborate. Defensive coordinator [[Ruffin McNeill]] was named interim head coach and led the team during their appearance in the Alamo Bowl.{{cite web |title=Texas Tech fires Leach | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/bowls09/news/story?id=4781981 |work=ESPN.com | date = December 30, 2009| accessdate = December 30, 2009}}{{cite news|title=Texas Tech Fires Coach Mike Leach |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/31/sports/ncaafootball/31leach.html|work=New York Times|date=December 30, 2009|first1=Thayer |last1=Evans | first2=Pete | last2=Thamel | accessdate=May 12, 2010}} In a statement, Leach said that he believed the firing was motivated in part by simmering acrimony over the contract negotiations. He also said he planned to sue Texas Tech for wrongful termination. On December 31, Leach spoke with ''[[The New York Times]]'' in his first interview since being fired from Texas Tech. He said that he did not know where James had been taken, having only ordered him taken "out of the light." He claimed the controversy stemmed from Craig James' constant lobbying for more playing time for his son, whom he characterized as lazy and feeling entitled.Evans, Thayer; Thamel, Pete. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/01/sports/ncaafootball/01leach.html Leach Denies He Mistreated Player]. ''[[New York Times]]'', January 1, 2010. On January 8, 2010, Leach formally filed suit against Texas Tech for wrongful termination and other claims. He claimed that school officials not only fired him without cause, but issued defamatory statements in a willful attempt to keep him from being hired elsewhere.Carver, Logan G. [http://www.redraiders.com/2010/01/09/leach-lawsuit-claims-fraud-defamation/ Leach lawsuit claims fraud, defamation]. ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', January 9, 2010. During a deposition for the case obtained by the ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', Adam James admitted under oath that he found the closet incident "funny."[http://multimedia.lubbockonline.com/pdfs/Leach/depojames.pdf Adam James deposition] In May 2010, District Judge Bill Sowder dismissed all but one of Leach's claims on the grounds of [[sovereign immunity]], but he allowed Leach's claim for breach of contract to proceed, finding that Texas Tech had waived its immunity on this claim by its conduct. The judge also dismissed Leach's claims against three university administrators.McGowan, Matthew. [http://lubbockonline.com/filed-online/2010-06-01/sowder-rules-leach-sovereign-immunity "Sowder: Leach contract suit can advance, throws out other claims against Tech, individual"]. ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]'', June 1, 2010.[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=5240460 "Judge: Leach suit can move forward"], [[Associated Press|AP]] at ''[[ESPN.com]]''. June 1, 2010. Both parties have taken steps to appeal the decision, although Leach's attorneys have said they would drop their appeal if Texas Tech would do likewise and allow the breach of contract claim to proceed to a jury trial.McGowan, Matthew. [http://lubbockonline.com/local-news/2010-07-02/tech-takes-first-step-toward-appeal-leach-case "Texas Tech taking first step toward appeal in legal battle with Leach"], ''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]''. July 1, 2010. Early in 2011, [[Twelfth Court of Appeals of Texas|Texas 7th Court of Appeals]] ruled that Texas Tech was immune from Leach's claim of breach of contract but that Leach can claim non-monetary reparations''';''' Leach attorney Paul Dobrowski announced his intention to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of Texas]].{{cite news|title=Court frejects Leach's claim|newspaper=Daily Star |place=Hammond, Louisiana |page=2B |url=http://www.hammondstar.com/top_sports_stories/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130125041405/http://www.hammondstar.com/top_sports_stories/|archivedate=January 25, 2013|date=January 22, 2011 |accessdate=January 22, 2011}} Online publication delayed. In February 2012, The Texas Supreme Court rejected Leach's appeal without comment signifying their belief that Leach's lawsuit(s) were without merit. After that ruling, Texas Tech attorney Dicky Gregg stated "As we've said from the beginning, we were right on the law and the facts, and the (Texas) Supreme Court has just held that we were correct on the law."{{cite web|title=Mike Leach's appeal on lawsuit denied|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/7585199/mike-leach-texas-supreme-court-denies-appeal-wrongful-termination-suit-vs-texas-tech|publisher=ESPN.com|accessdate=February 17, 2012}} ''[[Friday Night Lights (TV series)|Friday Night Lights]]'' series creator [[Peter Berg]] has hinted that he has written a movie script for the characters from the TV series that is based on Leach's firing from Texas Tech. On August 6, Judge Sowder issued a summary judgement dismissing Leach's lawsuits against ESPN, Spaeth Communications, and Craig James. Leach's attorneys indicated they would appeal.{{cite web|url=http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2013/08/08/judge-ready-to-end-mike-leach-lawsuits/ |title=Judge Ready To End Mike Leach Lawsuits « CBS Dallas / Fort Worth |publisher=Dfw.cbslocal.com |date=August 8, 2013 |accessdate=October 29, 2016}} ===Post-Texas Tech=== In August 2010, Leach joined [[CBS College Sports Network]], where he worked as a color analyst with play-by-play announcer [[Roger Twibell]].{{cite news|first=Blair|last=Kerkhoff|title=Leach, Twibell paired for broadcasts|date=August 16, 2010 |url=http://campuscorner.kansascity.com/node/1049|work=[[Kansas City Star]]|accessdate=August 16, 2010|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819051554/http://campuscorner.kansascity.com/node/1049|archivedate=August 19, 2010}} In 2010, Leach joined host [[Jack Arute]] to co-host "College Football Playbook" on [[SiriusXM]] College Sports Nation Channel 91, which airs weekdays 12 pm – 3 pm ET.{{cite web|url=http://www.siriusxm.com/collegesports |title=SiriusXM College Sports Nation, Talk Radio - SiriusXM Radio |publisher=Siriusxm.com |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2016}} In 2011, Leach released an autobiographical book, ''Swing Your Sword: Leading the Charge in Football and in Life'', through [[Diversion Books]].[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/47719-perseus-distribution-and-diversion-books-enter-agreement.html Perseus Distribution and Diversion Books Enter Agreement]. ''PublishersWeekly.com''. June 23, 2011.Deitsch, Richard. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/writers/richard_deitsch/08/08/kirkherbstreitohiostate.media/ ESPN's Kirk Herbstreit talks broadcasting, Ohio State] ''Sports Illustrated''. August 9, 2011. The book debuted at #6 on [[The New York Times Best Seller list]].[https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2011-08-07/hardcover-advice/list.html Hardcover Advice & Misc.]. ''NewYorkTimes.com''. July 31, 2001. Leach was considered by many in the national media to be a candidate for the head coaching vacancies at University of Miami, University of Maryland, and University of Minnesota following the 2010 regular season. After at least two interviews at Maryland, he was considered the frontrunner for that job until the administration decided instead to hire [[Randy Edsall]] away from University of Connecticut. Leach was mentioned in connection with a number of other vacancies in head-coaching positions during 2011, including [[Washington State Cougars football|Washington State]], [[Arizona Wildcats football|Arizona]], [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]], [[Kansas Jayhawks football|Kansas]], [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]], and [[Tulane Green Wave football|Tulane]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/tulane/index.ssf/2011/11/former_coach_leach_says_hes_no.html|title=Mike Leach says he's not in serious talks with Tulane|first=Tammy|last=Nunez|date=November 16, 2011|accessdate=November 26, 2011|newspaper=Times-Picayune}}{{cite news|url=http://tucsoncitizen.com/wildcatreport/2011/11/02/mike-leach-on-arizona-job-its-an-exciting-position/ |title=Mike Leach on Arizona job: 'It's an exciting position'|first=Anthony|last=Gimino|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=July 14, 2012 |newspaper=TucsonCitizen.com}} ===Washington State=== Leach agreed to terms with [[Washington State Cougars football|Washington State]] on November 30, 2011 and began coaching for the 2012 season. His five-year rollover contract made Leach the fourth-highest paid coach in the Pac-12.{{cite news |url=http://washingtonstate.scout.com/2/1134379.html|title=Mike Leach To Coach Washington State|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202023741/http://washingtonstate.scout.com/2/1134379.html|archivedate=December 2, 2011}} ====2012 season==== Leach's first season was a controversial one. Washington State was 3–9 overall and 1–8 in Pac-12 play; the lone wins were against FCS [[2012 Eastern Washington Eagles football team|Eastern Washington]], [[2012 UNLV Rebels football team|UNLV]], and an upset of rival [[2012 Washington Huskies football team|Washington]] in the Apple Cup. At the end of the season, more allegations of player abuse erupted on November 10, 2012 when star wide receiver [[Marquess Wilson]] quit the team citing "physical, emotional and verbal abuse" by the coaching staff.{{cite news|last=Bellencourt|first=Andrew|title=Washington State player quits citing Mike Leach abuse |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/pac12/2012/11/10/marquess-wilson-washington-state-leaves-team-coaching-abuse/1697021/ |publisher=USA Today|accessdate=November 11, 2012|date=November 10, 2012}} Immediately after the allegations were made, Washington State University President Elson Floyd issued a statement indicating that he had requested investigations into the alleged incident(s) from both the WSU Athletic Department and the Pac-12 Conference.{{cite web|last=Withers|first=Bud|title=WSU president wants probe of football program|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/sports/2019659656_wsuinquiry12m.html|publisher=Seattle Times|accessdate=November 11, 2012}} The investigations determined that the claims made against Leach were without merit, and Wilson later recanted the allegations.{{cite web |title=Marquess Wilson recants accusations against Mike Leach and Washington State's staff |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/ncaaf-dr-saturday/marquess-wilson-recants-accusations-against-mike-leach-washington-172000214--ncaaf.html |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |date=December 13, 2012 |accessdate=January 10, 2013}} Leach received a 2-year contract extension on November 18, 2013 after leading the Washington State Cougars to their best record since 2006.{{cite web|title = Mike Leach receives 2 year extension|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/9996715/mike-leach-contract-extended-washington-state-cougars|accessdate=November 18, 2013}} ====2013 season==== In 2013, Leach led WSU to a 6–6 regular season that had the Cougars Bowl eligible for the first time since 2003. The Cougars were led on offense by [[Connor Halliday]], who set school and conference records for passing. The Cougars defeated the [[University of Southern California]] Trojans, Southern Utah, The Idaho Vandals, The California Golden Bears, Arizona Wildcats, and the Utah Utes for a 4–5 conference record. The Cougars were invited to the [[New Mexico Bowl]] where they dropped a close game to the [[Colorado State Rams]] 48–45 after leading for much of the game. Leading by 16 points with under three minutes to play, the Colorado State Rams mounted an all-time great comeback, winning with a field goal as time expired in regulation. The Cougars led the nation in passing offense and total offense and Leach was awarded a pay raise for the Cougars 2013 performance. ====2014 season==== The 2014 season saw the Cougars regress back to a 3–9 record. The Cougars defeated Portland State 59–21, Utah 28–27, and Oregon State 39–32. ====2015 season==== In 2015, the Cougars had their breakthrough season of the Leach era with a 9–4 overall, 6–3 Pac-12 record. The Cougars were invited to the Sun Bowl where they beat Miami (FL) 20–14. This was the best Cougar record since the 2003 team went 10–3. ====2016 season==== The Cougars began the season 0-2, but rallied off 8 consecutive wins before dropping their final two games. The success of their season, led by Luke Falk at quarterback, landed them in the Holiday Bowl where they lost to Minnesota 17–12. They finished 7–2 in the Pac-12, with an overall record of 8–5 for 2016. Notable wins occurred against Oregon and #15 Stanford. The 2016 season was the Cougars best finish in Pac-12 conference play since the 2003. ====2017 season==== Washington State finished 6-3 in the Pac-12 and 9-4 overall. They were invited to the Holiday Bowl where they lost to Michigan State 42-17. ====2018 season==== Leach recruited graduate transfer [[Gardner Minshew]] at quarterback in time for the 2018 season and it paid big dividends. The Cougars won a school record-tying 10 games, the first time they had won that many in the regular season since 2002. They also surged as high as seventh in major polling. The Cougars went into the [[Apple Cup]] with a chance to clinch the Pac-12 North title and a shot at the Rose Bowl, but lost to rival Washington 28-15. ====Obama video controversy==== In June 2018, from his [[Twitter]] account, Leach retweeted a doctored hoax video of [[Barack Obama]]'s speech, produced by a [[conspiracy theory]] website and giving the appearance of Obama saying the opposite of what he actually meant. In the tweet Leach invited his followers to share their thoughts about the video, and he then spent several hours arguing with the critics of the video. Leach removed his original tweet of the video the next day and admitted that the video was ``incomplete".{{cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/wsu-cougar-football/qa-days-after-posting-doctored-obama-video-on-twitter-wsu-coach-mike-leach-has-much-more-to-say/|title=Q&A: Days after posting doctored Obama video on Twitter, WSU coach Mike Leach has much more to say|work=[[Seattle Times]]|first=Matt|last=Calkins|date=June 22, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} Leach did not apologize for the original tweet and engaged in a public dispute with the [[USA Today]] reporter Dan Wolken, who criticized the tweet{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/college/columnist/dan-wolken/2018/06/18/mike-leach-twitter-shows-why-bigger-schools-avoid-hiring-him/710530002/|title=Mike Leach's tweet of an anti-Obama hoax showed why many schools won't hire him|first=Dan|last=Wolken|work=[[USA Today]]|date=June 18, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} , and Leach challenged Woken to a twitter debate.{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mike-leach-starts-twitter-beef-usa-today-columnist-fake-barack-obama-conspiracy-video-041443198.html|title=Mike Leach starts Twitter beef with USA Today columnist over fake Barack Obama conspiracy video|work=[[Yahoo Sports]]|first=Ryan|last=Young|date=June 20, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} In a subsequent interview to [[Seattle Times]] Leach stated that he was “not particularly sorry” for the initial tweet of the video.{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/washington-state-lost-1-6-million-pledges-mike-leach-tweeted-fake-obama-video-152720804.html|title=Washington State: We lost $1.6 million in pledges after Mike Leach tweeted fake Obama video|work=[[Yahoo Sports]]|first=Nick|last=Bromberg|date=November 16, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} Shortly after the initial controversy, the [[Washington State University]] administration issued a statement saying that “As a private citizen, Mike Leach is entitled to his personal opinions" and that “Coach Leach’s political views do not necessarily reflect the views of Washington State University students, faculty and staff.”{{cite news|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/mike-leach-spends-fathers-day-arguing-twitter-heavily-edited-barack-obama-conspiracy-video-050851547.html|title=Mike Leach spends Father's Day arguing on Twitter about heavily edited Barack Obama conspiracy video|work=[[Yahoo Sports]]|date=June 18, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} In November 2018 the university President Kirk Schulz and Vice President Phil Weiler confirmed that as result of Leach's tweet about $1.6 million of planned [[Estate planning|donor estate gifts]] to [[Washington State University]] have been cancelled, although ``no one who had made a cash gift has asked for their money back".{{cite news|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/wsu-cougar-football/mike-leachs-tweet-of-doctored-obama-video-cost-wsu-1-6-million-in-estate-donations/|title=Mike Leach’s tweet of doctored Obama video cost WSU $1.6 million in donations|work=[[Seattle Times]]|first= Justyna|last=Tomtas|date=November 15, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} {{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/college-football/2018/11/16/mike-leach-obama-tweet-conspiracy-video-lost-donations-washington-state|title=Mike Leach's Obama Conspiracy Video Tweet Cost Washington State $1.6 Million in Donations|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|first=Jenna|last=West|date=November 16, 2018|accessdate=November 17, 2018}} ==Head coaching record== {{CFB Yearly Record Start | type = coach | * Four NCAA, 42 [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]], and 116 school records broken as [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]]'s offensive coordinator{{cite web |url=http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2008/11/18/Sports/Leach.Stoops.Past.Thickens.Plot-3548874.shtml |title=Leach, Stoops' past thickens plot|accessdate=November 21, 2008|publisher=[[The Daily Toreador]]|last=Ybarra|first=Alex|date=November 18, 2008 |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226024931/http://media.www.dailytoreador.com/media/storage/paper870/news/2008/11/18/Sports/Leach.Stoops.Past.Thickens.Plot-3548874.shtml|archivedate=February 26, 2009}} ===Texas Tech=== * 10 consecutive winning seasons * 8 consecutive seasons with at least 8 wins * 4 seasons with at least 9 winsIn 2009, the team had a total of 9 wins. However, since Leach did not coach the Alamo Bowl, the season is included in this list as an 8-win accomplishment for Leach. * 1 season with 11 wins * 9 consecutive bowl appearancesThe team won the [[2010 Alamo Bowl (January)|2010 Alamo Bowl]]. However, since Leach did not coach that game, it is not included in this tally. * 5 bowl wins (most by any individual coach in the history of the program) * 4 seasons completed with team ranked in the Top 25The team finished the 2009/10 season ranked in the top 25 of both the Coaches' and AP [[2009 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings|polls]]. However, since Leach did not coach the final game, the season is not included in this tally. * 19–11 record against in-state conference rivals [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor]], [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas]], and [[Texas A&M Aggies football|Texas A&M]] * 53–11 record at [[Jones AT&T Stadium]], home of the Texas Tech Red Raider football team * 2008 AP Big 12 Coach of the Year * 2008 Big 12 Coach of the Year * Coached 1 [[Fred Biletnikoff Award]] (Best Wide Receiver) winner: [[Michael Crabtree]] (two-time winner) * Coached 1 [[Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award]] (Best Senior Quarterback) winner: [[Graham Harrell]] * Coached 1 [[Mosi Tatupu Award]] (Best Kick Returner) winner: [[Wes Welker]] * Coached 3 [[Sammy Baugh Trophy]] (Outstanding Quarterback) winners: [[Kliff Kingsbury]], [[B.J. Symons]], and [[Graham Harrell]] * More than 150 NCAA, Big 12 and school records broken as Texas Tech's head coach * All-time winningest football coach in Texas Tech history{{cite web|title=Texas Tech University Record Book |url=http://issuu.com/techathletics/docs/2012ttu_records_book?mode=window&backgroundColor=%23222222|publisher=Texas Tech University Record Book}} ==Coaching tree== Although he did not play college football, Leach played wide receiver under John McDougall the long time coach at Cody High School in Cody, Wyoming, Under Coach MacDougall, Cody played in two top division state championships while Leach was a student, winning one in 1976 in triple overtime against legendary coach John Deti's Laramie Plainsmen. Head coaches under whom Mike Leach served: * [[Lyle Setencich]]: [[Cal Poly Mustangs football|Cal Poly]] (1987) * [[Hal Mumme]]: [[Iowa Wesleyan University]] (1989–1991), [[Valdosta State Blazers football|Valdosta State]] (1992–1996), [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky]] (1997–1998) * [[Bob Stoops]]: [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] (1999) Assistant coaches under Mike Leach who became NCAA head coaches: * [[Art Briles]]: [[Houston Cougars football|Houston Cougars]] (2003–2007), [[Baylor Bears football|Baylor Bears]] (2008–2015) * [[Jeff Choate]]: [[Montana State Bobcats football|Montana State Bobcats]] (2016–present) * [[Sonny Dykes]]: [[Louisiana Tech Bulldogs football|Louisiana Tech Bulldogs]] (2010–2012), [[California Golden Bears football|California Golden Bears]] (2013–2016), [[SMU Mustangs football|SMU Mustangs]] (2018–present) * [[Seth Littrell]]: [[North Texas Mean Green football|North Texas Mean Green]] (2016–present) * [[Greg McMackin]]: [[Hawaii In 1964 and 1966 Olympique Thiès has won the [[Senegal Premier League]].http://www.foot-base.com/en/CAF/Senegal/Olympique_Thies/ ==History== They played for many years in the top division the [[Senegal Premier League]] in Senegalese football. ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the [[Stade de Thies]]. ==Achievements== *'''[[Senegal Premier League]]: 5''' :: 1964, 1966 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.calciozz.it/equipa.php?id=8834 Calziozz] *[http://www.foot-base.com/en/CAF/Senegal/Olympique_Thies/ Footbase] {{Senegal Premier League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olympique Thies}} [[Category:Football clubs in Senegal]] [[Category:Sport in Thiès]] {{Senegal-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Peace and Friendship stadium | nickname = SEF | image = [[File:Peace and Friendship stadium 2014.JPG|280px|none]] | location = [[Neo Faliro]], [[Piraeus]], [[Greece]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|56|32.91|N|23|40|02.27|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1983 | opened = February 16, 1985[http://www.sef-stadium.gr/page4.html Λίγα Ιστορικά στοιχεία {{el icon}}.] | renovated = 2002–2004 | owner = Greek State | operator = [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]] | expanded = | surface = [[Parquet]] | architect = Thimios Papagiannis | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]]{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/competition/teams/showteam?clubcode=oly|title=Olympiacos Piraeus|publisher=Euroleague Properties|accessdate=4 April 2013}} | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]] 25 million (1983)

[[Euro|€]] 7.3 million (2002–2004) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]:
11,640[http://www.olympiacosbc.gr/en/team-en/peace-friendship-arena.html The Peace and Friendship Stadium.]
(permanent seating)
12,000[https://www.fosonline.gr/volleyball/eyropi/article/5287/etoimo-to-sef-gia-ton-teliko-olympiakos-ravena-pics Έτοιμο το ΣΕΦ για τον τελικό Ολυμπιακός-Ραβένα(pics) {{el icon}}.][http://redaroume.gr/%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF-%CF%83%CE%B5%CF%86-%CE%BC%CE%B5-%CF%84%CE%B7-%CF%81%CE%B1%CE%B2%CE%AD%CE%BD%CE%B1-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD-%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%80%CE%B1/ Στο ΣΕΦ με τη Ραβένα για την Κούπα! {{el icon}}.][http://ballineurope.com/euroleague-2016-17-preview-olympiacos-piraeus-5415/ Arena: Peace and Friendship Stadium aka the SEF (11,600/12,000).]

(during the [[Volleyball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens Summer Olympics]])
[[Indoor athletics]]: 10,520 }} The '''Peace and Friendship Stadium''', commonly known by its acronym '''SEF''' ({{lang-el|Στάδιο Ειρήνης και Φιλίας}}, transliterated as ''Stadio Eirinis kai Filias''), is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] that is located in [[Piraeus]], on the coastal zone of [[Attica (region)|Attica]], [[Greece]]. The arena is mostly known for being the home to [[EuroLeague]] team [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], and is the central venue of the [[Faliro Coastal Zone Olympic Complex]]. It opened in 1985. The arena complex also contains a 942-seat [[amphitheater]],[http://www.sef-stadium.gr/el/infrastructure/conference/melina-merkouri FACILITIES Places Exhibitions / Conferences - Melina Mercouri.] a weight training room, a full practice facility, three auxiliary courts that house the Olympiacos youth clubs,[http://www.olympiacosbc.gr/en/the-academy-en/the-facilities.html The facilities.] and the Olympiacos team office.[http://www.olympiacosbc.gr/en/management-en/olympiacos-bc-hq-en.html Olympiacos BC HQ.] ==History== The Peace and Friendship Stadium opened in 1985, and its construction cost was €25,000,000 in 1983 prices. It was designed by the architectural firm "Thymios Papagiannis and Associates". The arena is built opposite to the [[Karaiskakis Stadium]] in [[Piraeus]], located in the western end of the [[Phaleron Bay]], in the coastal zone of [[Attica (region)|Attica]]. It was inaugurated on February 16, 1985, at the first Panhellenic Athletics Indoor Championship, and hosted the [[1985 European Athletics Indoor Championships]] in March.[http://sef-stadium.gr/el/about-sef/stadium-history History] {{el icon}} Originally it was designed and operated for a dual use as a ice hockey rink and as basketball stadium. The first [[Greek Ice Hockey Championship]] was held in the stadium in 1989. The operation of the skating rink was stopped for the use of other sports. In 1991, the arena won the Golden Award from IAKS, the [[International Association for Sports and Leisure Facilities]].{{cite web|url=http://www.spaziomondo.com/page_progetto.cfm?id_progetto=50|title=Peace and Friendship Stadium|publisher=Mondo Spazio|accessdate=April 4, 2013}} Since the 1991–92 season, the Peace and Friendship Stadium has been the home court to [[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] and [[EuroLeague]] professional basketball club [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]]. The arena was closed from April 2002, to early 2004, for renovation works, at a total cost of €7,300,000, and hosted the [[Volleyball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|indoor volleyball]] tournament during the [[2004 Summer Olympics]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2004/or2004b.pdf 2004 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 2. p. 421. During the period that the arena was closed for renovations, Olympiacos played at the [[Glyfada Makis Liougas Sportshall]], during the [[2001–02 Euroleague|2001–02]] season, and at the [[Korydallos Sports Hall]], during the [[2002–03 Euroleague|2002–03]] and [[2003–04 Euroleague|2003–04]] seasons. The arena's total capacity varies, depending on the collapsible bleachers used in the lower level, besides its 11,640 permanent seating in the mid and upper levels,[http://www.olympiacosbc.gr/en/team-en/peace-friendship-arena.html The Peace and Friendship Stadium.] with additional temporary seating, it currently seats a total of 12,000 people for basketball games.[https://www.fosonline.gr/volleyball/eyropi/article/5287/etoimo-to-sef-gia-ton-teliko-olympiakos-ravena-pics Έτοιμο το ΣΕΦ για τον τελικό Ολυμπιακός-Ραβένα(pics) {{el icon}}.][http://redaroume.gr/%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF-%CF%83%CE%B5%CF%86-%CE%BC%CE%B5-%CF%84%CE%B7-%CF%81%CE%B1%CE%B2%CE%AD%CE%BD%CE%B1-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD-%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%8D%CF%80%CE%B1/ Στο ΣΕΦ με τη Ραβένα για την Κούπα! {{el icon}}.][http://ballineurope.com/euroleague-2016-17-preview-olympiacos-piraeus-5415/ Arena: Peace and Friendship Stadium aka the SEF (11,600/12,000).] The Peace and Friendship Stadium seats up to 14,776 for basketball games, with all the bleachers in use.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadia.gr/news/news-13-10-2001.html|title=Olympiacos B.C. move|publisher=stadia.gr|date=October 13, 2001|accessdate=April 29, 2013}} [[File:Peace and Friendship stadium.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]] and [[Orléans Loiret Basket|Orléans]] warm up before a [[EuroLeague]] game at the Peace and Friendship Stadium, in October 2009.]] [[File:VolleyballAt2004SummerOlympics-1.jpg|thumb|right|13,200 seat configuration during the [[Volleyball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Athens Summer Olympics Volleyball Tournament]].]] [[File:Kontogeorgakopoulou.jpg|thumb|right|250px|During the Greek figure skating championship (before 1991)]] ==Other uses== The arena is occasionally used for events like congresses, music concerts, and indoor [[motocross]] races. The [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]], [[Phil Collins]], [[Dire Straits]], [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]], [[UB40]], [[Gloria Estefan]], [[Deep Purple]], and [[Placebo (band)|Placebo]], are among the artists who have performed at the Peace and Friendship Stadium. Outside the main arena, in the same stadium building, there is a 942-seat [[amphitheater]], and various other halls of a total area of 16,048 sqm, where exhibitions and congresses take place.[http://www.sef-stadium.gr/files/presen.pdf Stadium Presentation Brochure.] ==Transportation== The Peace and Friendship Stadium is located in the [[Neo Faliro]] area of [[Piraeus]], on the coastal [[Poseidonos Avenue]], and at the end of the Kifissou Avenue. It is 2 km away from the [[port of Piraeus]]. It sits on a major transportation hub, next to the [[Faliro metro station]] on [[Athens Metro]] [[Line 1 (Athens Metro)|Line 1]], and the [[SEF tram stop|SEF station]], the terminus of [[Athens Tram]]. ==Notable events hosted== *[[Indoor athletics]] **[[1985 European Athletics Indoor Championships|1985]] [[European Athletics Indoor Championships]] *[[Volleyball]] **1989 [[CEV Champions League|European Champions' Cup]] Final **1992 [[CEV Champions League|European Champions' Cup]] Final Four **1993 [[CEV Champions League|European Champions' Cup]] Final Four **[[1994 FIVB Men's Volleyball World Championship|1994]] [[FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship|World Championship]] **[[1995 Men's European Volleyball Championship|1995]] [[Men's European Volleyball Championship]] **1996 [[CEV Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]] Final Four **[[2004 Summer Olympics]] – [[Volleyball at the 2004 Summer Olympics|Volleyball tournament]] **2005 [[CEV Cup|European Top Teams Cup]] Final Four *[[Basketball]] **[[1984–85 FIBA European Champions Cup|1985]] [[EuroLeague|FIBA European Champions' Cup]] [[1985 FIBA European Champions Cup Final|Final]] **[[EuroBasket 1987|1987]] [[EuroBasket]] **[[1988–89 FIBA European Cup Winners' Cup|1989]] [[FIBA Saporta Cup|FIBA European Cup Winners' Cup]] Final **[[1991 FIBA Centennial Jubilee Basketball Tournament|1991 FIBA Centennial Jubilee]] **[[1993 FIBA European League Final Four]] **[[1998 FIBA World Championship|1998]] [[FIBA Basketball World Cup|FIBA World Championship]] *[[Wrestling]] **1986 [[FILA Wrestling European Championships|European Championships]] **1988 World Cup (Greco-Roman Men's) **[[1999 World Wrestling Championships|1999]] [[World Wrestling Championships|World Championship (Greco-Roman Men's)]] * [[Gymnastics]] **[[1990 European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships|1990]] [[European Women's Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] **[[1991 World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships|1991]] [[World Rhythmic Gymnastics Championships]] * [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] **[[1999 World Weightlifting Championships|1999]] [[World Weightlifting Championships|World Championships]] ==See also== * revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = RZD Arena{{cite web|url=http://www.fclm.ru/en/club/stadium|title=RZD Arena - FC Lokomotiv Moscow|website=Fclm.ru|accessdate=1 August 2018}} | nickname = | image = Lokomotiv Stadium.jpg | image_size = 280px | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA Category 4 Stadium]]'''
[[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] [[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] [[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] [[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | location = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|48|13|N|37|44|28|E|type:landmark|display=it}} | publictransit = {{MOSMETRO-bull|1|}} [[Cherkizovskaya]]
{{MOSMETRO-bull|14|}} [[Lokomotiv (Moscow Central Circle)|Lokomotiv]] | broke_ground = 2000 | opened = 5 July 2002 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Russian Railways]] | operator = [[Lokomotiv Moscow]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $150-170 Million{{cite web|url=https://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2004/10/08/novyj-stadion-v-obmen-na-jelitnoe-zhile|title=Новый стадион в обмен на элитное жилье|date=8 October 2004|website=Vedomosti.ru|accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.odnako.org/almanac/material/stadion-zhelaniy/|title=Стадион желаний|website=Odnako.org|accessdate=1 August 2018}} | architect = Dmitry Bush | former_names = Stalinets, Lokomotiv | tenants = [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] (2002–present)
[[Russia national football team]] (selected matches) | website = {{URL|www.fclm.ru/en/club/stadium}} | seating_capacity = 27,320 | dimensions = 104m × 68m | events = }} [[Image:Lokomotiv-stadium.jpg|thumb|right|280px|Lokomotiv Stadium, before the game]] '''RZD Arena''' ({{lang-ru|«РЖД Арена»}}) is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. It is the home stadium of [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]] and was the home ground of the [[Russia national football team|Russian National Team]] for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]] matches. The stadium was reconstructed in 2002 and holds 27,320 people, all seated. The reconstruction of the stadium was funded by the [[Ministry of Transport (Russia)|Russian Transportation Ministry]] at a cost of $150–170 million. ==History== ===Stalinets=== In 1935, at the site where the Lokomotiv Stadium resides today, an electric workers union decided to build a stadium which was named "Stalinets" or "Stalinist Stadium". At that time Stalinets held about 30,000 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.oldmos.ru/photo/view/2891|title=Стадион «Сталинец», будущий «Локомотив»|website=PastVu|accessdate=1 August 2018}} ===Development of Lokomotiv Stadium=== After holding several key matches and establishing itself as a symbol of football in Moscow, Stalinets was demolished to make way for a more modern stadium. Thus, Lokomotiv stadium was built. It was opened on 17 August 1966 with a capacity of 30,000 people.{{Cite web |url=http://www.fclm.ru/ru/publications/news/13508 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-08-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805182133/http://www.fclm.ru/ru/publications/news/13508 |archive-date=2017-08-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} However, in the mid-90's the capacity of the stadium was reduced by 6,000 to 24,000, as the wooden benches were replaced by plastic seats. The inaugural match played at the '''Lokomotiv stadium''' was between [[Lokomotiv Moscow]] and [[Dynamo Kiev]]. As years rolled on, Lokomotiv held several important matches such as [[Russia National Football Team|Russian National team]] home matches, Lokomotiv matches and others. The stadium also played host to a European Cup Qualifier between [[FC Spartak Moscow]] and [[Swiss]] club [[FC Sion]]. The match finished 2-2; however, the Swiss club then forced UEFA to measure the posts for compliance with international standards. Indeed, the size of the posts were shown to infringe international standards. Eventually, UEFA ordered a replay, which [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak]] won 5-1. === Reconstruction === Despite the fact that Lokomotiv Stadium was still of good quality, the [[Lokomotiv Moscow]] board felt that a new stadium would be the best option. The construction was backed by the Russian Transport Ministry. The new stadium held its first match on July 5, 2002 when [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv Moscow]] welcomed [[FC Uralan Elista|Uralan Elista]]. The home team won 1-0 and the first official goal scored at the new stadium was an own goal by [[Dmitry Semochko]]. On 5 August 2017, [[Lokomotiv Moscow|Lokomotiv]] announced that the stadium has been renamed to '''RZD Arena''' following a deal with [[Russian Railways]]{{cite web|url=http://www.fclm.ru/ru/publications/news/15968|title=Заявление президента ФК «Локомотив» - ФК Локомотив|website=Fclm.ru|accessdate=1 August 2018}} ==Description== [[Image:LOKOSTADIUMPLAN.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Stadium Plan]] '''Lokomotiv''' was designed solely for football matches and thus has no running tracks. The pitch, which is 104mx68m, is surrounded by two-tiered four all-seater stands, the North Stand, the South Stand, the East Stand and the West Stand. The South Stand is home to the Lokomotiv Moscow ultras. On the other hand, travelling fans generally reside in the North Stand. All the stands are covered by a roof, by thus protecting the fans from the Russian harsh weather elements. The total areas of the glass roof is 20,000 square metres. A unique characteristic of the stadium are the VIP-Boxes found in between the upper and lower tiers of all the stands, with one of them being even a restaurant. Furthermore, the stadium comprises other three VIP-sectors, one of them being of soft-seats. Altogether they total to 974 VIP-seats. Furthermore, there are 156 seats available for the press. Thus in all the stadium holds 30,000 people. Moreover, beneath the stands one can find a fitness centre, a bowling club and also the offices of both the club and the fan club. Moreover, beside the stadium one can find the [[MSA Lokomotiv|Minor Sports Arena Lokomotiv]]. ==Concerts== [[Depeche Mode]] performed at the stadium on June 22, 2013 during their [[Delta Machine Tour]], in front of a sold out crowd of 27,886 people. ==See also== {{portal|Association football}} *[[List of football stadiums in Russia]] *[[List of European stadia by capacity]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Lokomotiv Stadium (Moscow)}} *[http://www.fclm.ru/en/club/stadium/ RZD Arena] *{{Ru icon}} [http://www.unitedsouth.ru/readarticle.php?article_id=14 Article about the stadium] {{s-start}} {{Succession box | title=[[FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship]]
Final Venue| before=[[Rajamangala National Stadium]]
[[Bangkok]]| after=[[Estadio Municipal de La Florida|Estadio Bicentenario Municipal]]
[[La Florida, Chile|La Florida]]| years=[[2006 FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship|2006]] }} {{s-end}} {{FC Lokomotiv Moscow}} {{Russian Premier League venues}} [[Category:FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] [[Category:Football venues in Russia]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Russia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Moscow]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Russia]]
